Review_Text: My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.
Fun workplace with passionate co-workers. If you love pets and helping pet owners, this is the place for you. However, you must have passion for it because the pay is not there.
Work hard paid not so hard. Not easy to advance and if you do you are over worked. Trading commission is okay but only if you can sell tons. A lot income store doesn't do that
My time here was super slow paced and everyone just seemed like they just wanted to go home, which is valid. Employees were occasionally nice but overall it was depressing.
The Culture Petsmart has created is great. I felt welcomed and had an overall good time in the DC. Pay is good, they were very flexible with me going to school. I had no real complaints.

The coworkers and managers will talk behind your back. Tips are okay, most of the coworkers would belittle you or make you feel incompetent. They would schedule you without telling you and get mad you didn't show up. Its okay but be prepared to do more work and yelled at for not being "fast enough"  don't be ontime but 5 minutes early

Overworked and underpaid sums it up. I enjoy working with the dogs. I just started out about a month ago as a bather and will be attending the grooming academy, hopefully. I wasn't aware that I would have to give up every weekend to work and plus closing at all times.
This was a nice start to my career working with animals. The basic training provided for animal care was sufficient and helped guide me to more focused animal welfare efforts.
I did not like working there because of the way they treated the small animals. Staff was cool. But the birds and fish were not treated the best. It was om for a starting job

The job itself isn't too bad, but the only thing leadership cares about is making money and keeping customers. Not all managers care about their associates and the ones that do are few and far between. No matter what a customer does, if they complain to the manager or corporate they get what they want

I feel that corporate doesn't understand the needs of the store with the hours given to us. we usually close the store with 3 people and this is ok sometimes. However over the past year it has not. During the evening shifts we often on busy days only have 3 people on in the store with one cashier, one leader and one pet care associate. I order to provide the best customer service the leader is forced to chose whether to become back up cashier, help customers or help in pet care when they are backed up. Our customers reflect their experience with this in customer surveys.

PetSmart wants to pay you the minimum and then give you every task known to man. Someone called out? Too bad. Figure it out without them. Didn’t get everything completed due to lack of staff? Too bad, here’s your write up. Need to call out because your legitimately sick? Get over it and get to work. You tested positive for covid? Well why’d you come to work sick? Because you made me!! I seriously cannot stress to you enough... there are not enough words in the English dictionary for me to explain to you and caution you on how awful company is and how it drains you of every spark of energy that you think you have! And then they wanna play the whole “make associates feel like they belong” .. “we care about you and your health” .... Total front. Not to mention the lack of support. You’ve got one person over here with their head so far up the SL’s cheeks that you’re unsure of which one is actually the SL. Another one over here busting it, while that person over their is getting all the credit. Just don’t. Don’t apply. I’m gonna stop now. But I could go on for days.
It's fun to play with dogs at PetsHotel but unfortunately Petsmart is very bureaucratic with too many policies that get in the way of common sense, leading to high turnover.

When I began at Petsmart 10 years ago, it was a great place to work. But this gradually changed to what it is now: a place where the store and services employees are treated like chattel, while upper management at the home office in Arizona issue decrees from on high that aren't in line with in reality. Store and services workers are expected to perform an ever increasing amount of work with less -- less pay, less labor hours allocated, and less support.

The supervisors and team leads are clicky and don't let anyone they don't like succeed. They change their opinion about agents within a day and will randomly pick people to abuse their power. You might be sitting with a team of 18 people and then the next day 9. Quality Assurance and other parts are bogus for the most part and can't actually help the agents grow. They let people work from home in waves when the pandemic first hit because they didn't fund enough equipment in preparation. and they made some of us stay for like 3 months into it all, also the people chosen to work from home were not picked based on performance or tenor, but rather favouritism (THE WORST PART) and barely any compliance with social distancing. I had other people around me who literally just got done traveling across state within 14 days and I got covid from them. When I told them about my concerns they brushed it off every time with a "yeah... unfortunately that's just how it is [*Smiley Face* :)  if it was an IM just to be even more petty.] And also because its like company protocol to have no expression of worry and a "CAN DO" attitude the whole time even when just casually speaking to peers on break. Not really a ton of room to move up and if you mess up once on like your first day, you have to wait like 6 months to have that problem removed from your account.
The store is great my dogs loves to go there and the people are nice and you guys have lots of food brands and toys that I love and they love to I like cats to and …

I worked here in college and it was okay. My manager was okay but the pay was minimal and my raise was 25 cents...which is ridiculous. Customers were nice. There didnt seem to be much culture at my store.
I absolutely love working here. I worked at another big retail store before transferring to the life of pets and I cannot express enough how much happier I am now!

the job is relatively easy; being a cashier, stocking shelves, and a heavy focus on customer service. customer service/getting sales is their biggest priority. don’t get sick and call out, or they’ll get upset.

I worked in the PetsHotel area of PetSmart and I can say it was quite fun. You get to work with dogs and sometimes cats but it kind of sucks cause you have to clean all the gross stuff but after awhile you get used to it. The managers made sure you had your break and there is room to grow! I was almost promoted (at the time I only worked for a few months) but then covid came so that blew right out the window. One big con is that the managers and team leaders had no back bone. If there was a serious issue with an employee they would barely do anything. Or if someone wasn’t doing their job right, they would say something one time but that was it and then get mad when the employee would do it again but still they wouldn’t do anything about it. But other than that still a decent job.

At first working here was ok, however I quickly learned that every one else was making more than I was and getting a raise is close to impossible. Made me bitter about going the extra mile and not getting any recognition for it. I was a petcare specialist, however they often would put me to work on the register which no one wanted to do. Also management would often make “jokes” or degrade petcare staff making it seem like their job was easier than it was. The only good thing about this job that I can think of it was that it was easy to call out of/get days off or people to cover for you.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

Being told from day one about going to grooming school is the only thing that has kept me going, the pay is absolutely absurd barely covers my phone bill & food, i do like getting paid weekly but that is probably the only plus side to this job. Expected to not only do about 4-6 dogs in 5 hours but also expected to answer every phone call (managers only care about the customers) & help the groomers with whatever they need done because THEYRE running behind. I feel that I am treated like i’m a peasant lol. On top of all of that we are extremely limited on hours as bathers which barely gets me $200 a week talk about SAD. I do not recommend this job if youre starting out because you WILL be promised so much more than you will be given. Do not expect a lot out of this job as the company only cares about making their money & not helping their employees or making the daily workplace any easier.

Mostly my shift started at 4am to work the truck, but sometimes I would work the register. It’s an okay job but it comes with big box store issues, like chronically being short handed. It’s like they hired and kept employees who didn’t care about their jobs.

Great job to work as a part time college student. Managers in north 10th put customers first and bend over backwards to answer any questions. Pay is great hours are very flexible and managment is near perfect.
Management is awesome
I love working petcare. Everyone is friendly and the manager is flexible with my schedule. Animals are number one priority with each employee! Definitely recommend

The management is helpful and understanding. The culture within my store is very accommodating and friendly. People accept you for who you are and love to point out the good things you do. There are opportunities to move up, especially if you're willing to relocate.

Too many dogs, not enough associates to care for them. Pay was abysmal for all that we had to put up with. I got plenty of hours because of the high turn over, but I was always stressed with all the dogs I had to care for myself since we were pretty understaffed. Also management was cutting corners in terms of "walking" the dogs.

This is by far my favorite job so far! The managers are awesome and everyone I worked with was so nice. Being around animals every day was such an amazing experience and always brightened my day up. I formed an attachment to all my regulars at doggie day care.

Usual understaffed even pre-covid creates a fairly stressful environment. Even when staffed the company does little to create an inclusive environment. Employees often create a hostile workplace for each other and solutions are not team building. They do not practice any kind of team building so it's to be expected that information between employees isn't fluid. Communications are often minimal which can be confusing. Animal care knowledge is minimal as well and it's often beneficial for employees to spend personal time educating themselves. This can often lead to frustrations as the focus is in sales of products. However, scheduling tends to be on-demand as low staffing creates openings for either extra hours or specific hours. Pay isn't competitive and level caps without a ladder system for advancement means raises are low.

Definitely a company that sees you as disposable. Managers and corporate make it very clear that they do not care about you unless you’re boosting their numbers. Worked at more than one location and always saw managers that were under qualified for their jobs or just overwhelmed by the workload. Salon teams are usually constantly overwhelmed, expected to each groom up to 6 dogs a shift while also being expected to answer the phone that rings off the hook all day. You start out as a bather and then end up going to academy to be a groomer (if your manager even wants you to). Pay for the bather position is trash and 100% not worth the manual labor that you do. I lost 30lbs as a bather and wasn’t out of shape to begin with. Policy says you’re not supposed to lift over a certain weight but the groomers never have time to help you lift dogs so you’re on your own.

Management sucks and tends to pick favorites,very repetitive, pay isn't worth what they put you through, expect you to do everyone else's job including theirs without giving extra pay. But working with the animals is alot of fun..

The Petsmart I have worked at is very small but has some of the nicest customers that come in. Often people ask questions for petcare and how to properly setup animal husbandry. Of course there is always a odd person here and there who are a bit spiteful. But overall great place to work.
Great to work with animals and be able to talk to others about animals, but pay is limited and the only advancement requires early morning stocking shifts.
Hard place to work when you have children.  My pay was not great for the amount of work required.  It is taxing to deal with angry customers so much.  I enjoy working with animals
You get to do a ton of stuff when you work at petsmart and it is especially fun for animal lovers, But just like any retail job it has its cons, which if you're used to it won't be a bother.
The pay is too low compared to the work put in. Some days I’d have to clock out for my lunch and immediately go back to work just so I can finish the dogs on my schedule.

I've had a couple good store managers here but for the most part management is a joke. I worked in grooming. Their training is ridiculously bad (I was trained elsewhere). They say they want quality over quantity but that's a lie. All corporate looks at are numbers and couldn't care less about you as a person. Grooming management is either power tripping or looking to move on or both. If you know what your doing you can make more money being a groomer. They write their policy and procedures for inexperience and stupidity.
Been with them for three years always willing to teach and promote from within.  Most stores setup very similar so easy to move within the system for promotions.

Coworkers are generally good, I enjoyed them quite a bit but the management is always on your back and ready to reprimand you for your work no matter the situation without opportunity to explain yourself.

Pet Smart can and has been in the past, a great place to work. They pay me well. The down side is advancement. I am teaching my boss his job and he just can't catch on after 9 months. He makes the big money while I am hourly.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.
This was the best job I've ever had. I worked in the PetsHotel and PetSmart takes care of their employees. We got free speakers to use in the DayKamp center and it was great! Highly Recommend.
The best part of this job is seeing the animals. The hours are long and repetitive. Working the trucks can get repetitive, especially if it's the same stuff over and over.
fun place to work with room for growth, management helps you when they can. have responsibilities to care for the animals, which is a good thing. Nice customers too
Corporate is always looking at the numbers and micro manages. Focus on your negatives more than your positives. Yet to hear them compliment me or a coworker.

Felt under appreciated as an employee! At the end of the day it was only about the numbers! They often punish employees who have appointments or go home sick by cutting their hours down. When you put in your notice they list you as no rehire!

My team is by far the best part of my job. I’ve worked at PetSmart for 3 almost 4 years. I worked my way up a regular associate to management.  At first it was great but with covid hours were cut regardless of how busy all the stores have been with “quarantine pets.”Corporate keeps taking away required tasks or telling us to do them less often to justify the lack of hours but doing things like animal counts less often make numbers much less accurate and it takes me more to to do them once a month than it did once a week. We still have the same amount of tasks to complete and not enough hours. It has made the job very stressful and I feel as though there is never enough time in the day.

I love my coworkers and working with animals. However, PetSmart is very much a large corporation that values quantity over quality in almost all areas. Compensation definitely needs to be higher, especially for those working directly with animals. Again, I love working with animals, but I come home sore and covered in bruises and scratches every single day. I feel as though they should be paying us more for the physical labor and risk of injury.

Work sometimes gets busy during weekend afternoons. Management seems to care for employees, and form connections. Employees seem to trust one another and gets along well. Petcare associates know their stuff and try to give customers good advice, but oftentimes customers ignore us. You will sometimes deal with angry customers but management will always intervene to help you out. Overall a good place of belonging. Most workers are in college though.

Working in the salon is fun and the dogs make it almost worth it. However it is an underpaid position for the amount of work and customer service aspect. Work-life balance is abysmal. They’ll say they evenly try to schedule weekends and holidays, but you will be there for weekends and holiday. Once heard a manager discouraging employees to grow their families.

The best part of working for Petsmart is getting to see all the regular customers and their pets as long as they are responsible pet parents.. Besides for that....petsmart used to be a pretty good company.  Of course like all big companies they are always trying to be more profitable so they keep cutting labor. They've cut so many hours, positions in the store that it's impossible to get your work done.  I've worked with an amazing team that stuck with it all through covid but it's finally becoming too much.  We're starting to lose some amazing staff members because their done with corporate piling on more and more, all the while paying low wages and pretending they care.  No. Petsmart does not care about any of their associates or they would give back some hours so our petcare team isn't overworked. Cashiers are always stressed out because now it's only 1 vs having overlapping coverage. They are tired of being the only cashier and hearing customers complain constantly because merchandise isn't on the shelves.... that's because we get very few hours for stocking, long lines....because there's only 1 cashier.

They give very little training and then if you make an error they rate you up immediately. They also will cut your hours in half without telling you till you see it and they do not accommodate for appointments

PetSmart was a great company to work for when I started 15 years ago. Over the years the company cut hours until the stores were constantly understaffed. It became less important to offer excellent customer service than to save as much money as possible on overhead and as a result you can expect to make less money for more work and deal with more justifiably irrate customers who will cause you more stress than you need. I stuck with it as long as I did because I was and still am passionate about teaching people about their pets, but now that I have the opportunity, I prefer to either find an organization that takes pride in the actual work of dog training, or starting one of my own.

While the job has a lot of upside, the downside certainly outweighs it. Regardless of your position there is much to be done and no time to do it. Management is poor as far as communication and although they preach we work as a team, everybody is only does tasks that benefit themselves. Most everybody is quick to point fingers when something is done wrong or a mistake has been made, and just as quick to take praise for the good that has been done. To anyone seeking employment at petsmart, be prepared to lose your soul.
The job isn’t too bad. The dogs were the best part of the job. It was nice once you got a good clientele in place. Being trapped in that glass room was sometimes annoying.

I was hired in 2015, right after they were bought by their current owners but before the current p&p was established, so I have an unfortunately unique view of seeing the decline of the company. I really, really loved my job from 2015-2017, and then due to frequent manager changes and policy changes, it became a much more stressful and hostile work environment. It was more difficult to get animals to the vet, care commitments were changed for the worse, etc.

Fast paced at times but over all pretty relaxed. The petcare position was fun, and all of my co workers were easy to get a long with. This position is for people who are truly passionate about working with animals and puts a lot of care into taking care of them. Cashier position also isn’t too bad, rarely were there rude customers.

I love the job itself even though it can be stressful in the petcare department. But the managers make it unbearable sometimes. Never agreeing on what they want so they are constantly telling you different things and chewing you out for it. Plus the hours are horrible.
I liked working for petsmart because you can always advance. Biggest downfall is its a corporation. Im just personally not a corporation type of person
It was good for a college job, but the customers tear you down. You're told you can deny sales but then your DM tells you you're not allowed, as it will lead to bad customer reviews.

I worked for petsmart as a Groomer for 10 years. The turn over is so high. Groomers are pushed to groom more and more to make the store more money all the while they are expected to still answer phones, book appointments, check in clients, and spend at least 10 minutes with each for check in and check out. People who have never groomed sit around and come up with ideas of how to make a salon better but have no idea what they are talking about.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.
Hard physical work, but can pay off if you're a groomer. Bathers get paid hourly while groomers start at 40% and after completing academy go to 50%
Overall, It serves a purpose, you get paid weekly. Schedule comes out 2 weeks in advance so you can plan a life outside of work. I like being able to move around and try new departments.

Not bad but not great either. Worked directly with dogs so I didn't have to deal with customers which is a plus for me. Worst part is when no one wants to dump the waste buckets the shift before leaving with a mess

Never enough staff to give good customer service yet we were told it was up to us to make sure every customer was taken care of. Poor management. Company constantly told grooming salon workers that safety came first but did not provide them with the tools and staffing needed to always put safety first. Always feeling pressure from company to up-sell and groom more dogs than possible.
Good. Liked the people. Different for each person and store. get to see animals and meet a lot of nice people. i had a lot of fun working and 10/10!!!
The things that stand out to me working here are the passion from the other employees about the animals they care for and send out to good homes. I've learned a lot from them in my short time here.

They are money driven don’t have a care about the animals health or the groomers if a groomer doesn’t feel comfortable they push the groomer anyways or force the pet onto someone else. Short breaks if you got them the people there are very rude and not team players managers only care about how much money you could make they have favorites. They work the ones who will work to death to the point they hate their jobs and the ones that call out constantly or show up late all the time are fine never get in trouble.
This was a good place to work, however I was not given the position I applied for. I got hired for pet care, but instead of working for pet care I only worked the register.

These things really depend on the region and individual stores. That being said, pay is seldom adequate and not evenly distributed. If you accept a lower wage thinking it will go up, it may take years. People with no experience will make more money just starting out, but employees that have been there over 5 years will have only received a yearly 10 cent raise if their performance was ranked well. Job can be enjoyable if you need something temporary or have other income to rely on. You can learn a lot about differerent animal and fish species if you take the time to read on your own time.

Great job!! usually on weekdays in the morning there would be nothing much to due, but you still got paid hourly so you could see yourself sitting around for about 1-2 hours doing nothing (this depends on which store you're applying for), aside from the occasional walk-in. They sometimes hold special adoption days, where you can meet with future customers and dogs. the job usually includes making appointments, cleaning (sweeping, cleaning the bathing area, etc...), grooming and bathing the pets that come in, and answering customer questions, which they go over in their training period (which you get paid for). You get paid a decent amount of money and you also get tips. Overall great place to work at!!

Getting to see happy and loving animals everyday is a huge plus, but it’s a retail job very focused on sales. Typically its very easy to request time off and see family, but being a part time associate does not yield any benefits outside of a paycheck. While the staff I work with are awesome, the grind of a corporate job focused on sales and reviews will weigh you down and all you can do is try and provide the best information/advice for a pet parent, but more often than not, they will not take your advice and either return an animal they did not research and blame you or the animal suffers. It is a very hard cycle to be part of as an animal lover. You will learn all sorts of tips and tricks here for taking care of animals though, even from my role as cashier! Be prepared to only receive a lunch during an 8 hour shift though, it is near impossible to receive a break. There is rarely enough help either.
It sucks. Pay Is awful, pet parents are entitled and management sucks extremely. I don’t recommend working here unless you want to have the life sucked out of you.
Worked there for a little bit as a pet care associate, management was great. Fun if you like animals, if you don't, why are you applying, part time pay not the best, but alright
pretty good job i had good co workers i never thought the benefits would be this great free lunches YUM i eat on the job and i use the bathroom to vape

I worked there for about two years and I ended up getting trained in all areas except for training, management, and a groomer but I was a dog Bather trying to become a groomer. I was told by one of the lower managers that if I got trained in most of the jobs at the store I would be able to become full-time. Which I manage to learn almost all of the positions But unfortunately they worked me almost full-time hours for a couple weeks and then I would get one really low week so that way they could keep me  as part time. And when I became a dog bather trying to become a full-time groomer they kept pulling me out of my training to help them back out on the floor. Then when it came time for grooming Academy I ended up not having enough training hours to become a groomer and there wasn’t going to be another one For seven more months. I was a very dedicated and hard-working employee but that did not matter they did not want me to be full-time because then they would have to give me benefits

The store management overall are great but Corporate does not listen to their employees. I was not happy about how Corporate treated their cashiers. They forget we can make or beak a store. Cashiering is so key to the store. I will say my store leader was fair and wonderful to work for
I enjoyed working here because I love animals but if you get bad management it will make the time here miserable.

It's PetSmart. The one I worked at didn't care about their employees, the managers would constantly make fun of other managers, employees and customers when no one else was around. They maybe flexible with your schedule but they'll complain about it. And one of the managers over the early morning stocking would call you at 8 pm that night to make you come in at 1 or 2 in the morning when your scheduled to come in at 4 or 5 without warning.
Since it is cooperate your constantly waiting on a higher up and it feels like your not important or ‘annoying’ your mangers. But overall it’s a good support system in the store I worked at.
The staff got along really well. Training was good. The business was very organized and professional. I enjoyed working there. Unfortunately I had to leave because of unexpected health issues.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.
The job was okay. We were always short staffed and many people would quit. Some of the managers showed favoritism and other would work harder than others.
Very good place to work. Good management. Great customer service. Fun environment.  Flexible work schedule.  Overall a great place to work especially if you love animals
If you work here use it to you’re advantage management is hit and miss; be there for the education not the job or the money. Be ready to get out when your contract is up.

The job is very fast paced and there’s a lot that needs to be done during your shift. If you’re fully staffed it’s a pretty smooth process but if you’re ever short staffed it really makes the day difficult to get through. Working with the dogs is rewarding and overall the job is cool but just be prepared for unexpected stress.

Worked there a long time and enjoyed it when we were a smaller company. As we grew the family feeling went away. Managers get moved around a lot so you never settle in with one group of people before they move out and new people move in.

The pethotel was gross, staff and management were extremely lazy and judgemental. There was no outside area for the dogs to go to the bathroom they just potty in their rooms or in the playroom. The playroom only got cleaned twice a day and the rooms rarely got scrubbed. Nasty.

At a store level, it is an interesting and fun place to work. Home office decisions are confusing and sometimes unwarranted, sometimes even detrimental to the success of the store. Even though they offer advancement opportunities and training, seems as if though in order to move up, it'd be better if you were an outside higher. Clear evidence of advancement, but after a decade or more of being within a store.

This job is not worth the money spare yourself. PetSmart policies try to protect their animals legally, but their emphasis is on blind sales. Most of the employees have no idea about care for animals or the products they need to sell with animals. Most employees did not care about the animals at all let alone have any knowledge about them to help a customer. Daily I would have to step in and explain to a customer how to care for their pet and what their pet needed because there was only a handful of people in the store that knew anything about the pet. Breaks are short. Store was not cleaned properly. Terrible management, no teamwork or communication.
You'll often times find yourself doing work that you didn't sign up for unbeknownst to you. The managers are pretty lazy and will drain the life out of you if you let them.

There is some toxicity within the grooming salons based upon expectations and locations in the area. You are expected to make a large profit for the company, so cycling through dogs is more important than the finished product. Some management doesn't uphold the policies  as strictly while other management does. At the same time some are more lenient on schedules than others. It all depends on which location you work at, and what values you hold onto.
Not enough staff or time to get the job done. Irregular schedule and working with people who hated being there. Out of touch upper management who look down on employees.

Not supportive to you, deletes your online enrollments, they want you to be on register and you have no time to prepare for classes, do training paperwork and ylu have to share your space with the PetsHotel but receive but I was told they would sell boot camp classes for me, they have done none. Management sucks, and I recieve 20% commission when I do 100% of the work

I've never seen so many managers in and out in a company. My Store leader is very arrogant and likes to be intimidating. So many good employees and managers left because of his lack of leadership  skills.

I worked in the Petshotel "Mostly overnight shifts"  I've never had so much fun in a workplace. The dogs and cats were amazing and on the overnight shift you can work at your own pace, as long as everything is done by the am shift, everything is cool. You can play music and hang out with doggies all night...

Generally, PetSmart is a good place to work. I have found that the company sometimes works on too many priorities at the same time and is very slow to provide the resources in terms of headcount needed to get the job done. You have to know when to say "I can't get to this right now" PetSmart can be a great place to learn because you get involved in a lot of things. Can you get promoted here? Yes, but it can take longer than you anticipate. It is also according to how your department operates and some have their favorites, making it hard for many to get opportunities to advance. The company does a good job at recognizing employees through cash awards and a points catalog. As far as remote work, some leaders are old fashioned and think that if they can't see you, you are probably not working. There are pockets in the business, however, that allow remote work. You will find that most of the employees are pet centric which makes for a fun environment. All in all, I would recommend PetSmart as an employer.

I have worked at Petsmart for 3 years. I've done some Hotel/Doggy Daycare work, cashier/floor work and I was a bather for a year and then became a groomer which I've been for 2 years. My biggest issue is rules seem to vary store-store & district-district. Also, corporate is very insistent on groomers and bathers overlooking themselves and forcing add-ons onto people, and the haircuts are cheap ($76 for a doodle is way too cheap) so it attracts some of the worse customers. Corporate seems to always take the customers side and not the employees side. I wish corporate would care more about making employees happy than making customers happy. You can't have happy customers without happy employees.

For a little while I really loved working there but I didn’t feel like I had a fair chance to be a permanent part of the PetSmart team and they agreed to work with my schedule for school but went back on that agreement when it no longer benefited them.

The PetSmart call center was one of the easiest jobs I have ever had. Before the pandemic, they offered free food and many events which was super fun! Once the pandemic hit back in April 2020, they offered all agents to work from home which was also very convenient. The only thing I would say that Petsmart needs to work on is making sure all supervisors and leads were on the same page because sometimes everyone would have different answers and it could get confusing. I will say one con is it is hard to move up within the company and it can get competitive. If you want to go for a leadership role you will have to go for it multiple times until you maybe get the position. You are basically waiting for a position to get announced and that can take months to a year depending on when someone quits and when you go for it the chances of you getting it are a 10/100 because everyone goes for it so they can get off the phones. Also some supervisors are willing to help their agents grow within the company and help them as much as they can where as other supervisors don't care as much which isn't one hundred percent fair. I noticed many co workers from other teams got promoted but none from my team did. I think all supervisors should guide each agent to success and help them grow within the company fully because that is very important. However all of management was very friendly to me and helped me when I needed. When covid restrictions have been lifted the past couple of months, the call volume has increased big time since everyone is trying to go on vacation so there is about 80 calls

Was a fun job, but corporate limited our resources due to budget and hired, in my opinion, some very unprofessional people due to, I’m guessing, desperation. Pay isn’t that great. I worked a lot of the same shifts on holidays each year. Eh.

Expect you to do the work of 3 people good staff and nice people though opportunity for advancements the pay is not that great really good start for people wanting to be in pet care a trainer or grooming. Customers always right attitude though it is what you make it.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

As a previous review said, WATCH YOUR BACK. It’s very clique based and if you’re not a favorite you aren’t anything. I’ve never loved a job more but had to leave due to the people and management. It breaks my heart. They DO NOT CARE about you. I got one 30 min break my whole shift, some days I didn’t even get that.

I worked at petsmart for a year and it was really fun, i loved the different personalities of the animals and their pet parents. Salon's management went downhill after the manager had a pregnancy leave tho

Worked as a dog groomer here for 5 years. Management constantly pressuring us to take more animals than we felt comfortable taking, no sense of pride in the quality of the grooms coming out the door, new and inexperienced groomers let loose with minimal training. Often times was pressured to take dogs that were unsafe either due to age or aggressive behavior. Management only cares about profits, and half the time we didn't even have the necessary supplies like clean towels or shampoo to do the job. Also, the timers on the air dryers would shock people randomly and no one ever came to fix it, and the cages were sitting up on paint cans etc due to the amount of water in the back from clogged drains. This place makes more than enough to address these issues, but they refused to spend the money because it would make their profits look bad.
Manager was always criticizing what you did, couldn’t have flexible hours, pay was poor for all you had to do, customers were always rude and the manager would never have your back

It's a job; it's fine. Cashier work is never the most engaging, so don't expect that. But it is easy work, sometimes your feet just get tired. Also it is definitely energizing to see the pets people bring in!
The team is really supportive of each other and it's fun to help new customers find exactly what they need for their pets.  Overall a fun and rewarding place to work!
Great for beginners to jump into the Pet Grooming industry. You’ll have to teach yourself to do style cuts but practice will be had at a steady rate. Competitive pay for salon leadership to start.

While working at petsmart, I’ve met some great people. Sadly, this does not make up for the horrible pay and the stressful work. Being just a dog bather seems simple and fine till you realize you have to do 10 baths a day plus any walk in services, deal with bad dogs and the owners, and help out in the store, if they’re behind, for only $10 an hour.  That “wonderful” pay is only if you’re full time. If Bathers were paid commission they’d make a livable wage, but they’re not.
Just come to work and go home. You'll be fine. Management is okay, they have your back. Customers are kind of demanding. High volume of overturn. Salon is good.
Pros: Interacting with pets. Most coworkers have a "in this together" attitude.

If you care about animals, don’t work here. This place doesn’t care about you or any living being that comes through the door. The staff I work with are great, but the company as a whole will break your spirit. I started off very blind and excited to “work with animals” and “care for the animals.” That’s just not the reality. You are forced to sell these vulnerable little creatures to people who don’t really care about them and hope that they make it.

Company really doesn’t care about the employees, just their image. Work employees to death, distrust managers come in on busy weekends and yell at employees in front of customers, just focuses on numbers and not employee happiness, CONSTANTLY CUTS LABOR!!!! A full time position is 36 hours max. Only 2 weeks PTO, 2 sick days and 2 misc days and god forbid if a loved one dies. Management is spread very thin and communication throughout the company sucks. Technology like registers, phone, scan gun, website are dinosaurs. Pay is very minimal and not comparative at all.
I worked as a cashier for a few years until I was laid off due to the pandemic. Being around animals helped relax me and my managers often gave me praise for how well I handled customers

all Petsmart really cares about as far as groomers go is how much money they can make the company. They push newer groomers to do many more dogs than they should be doing and therefore had many pet incidents and stressed out employees.
Expected to do more than what your title is. Very hard to move up if you’re not close with the other managers. Dealing with al the departments like a manager but not being paid the same.

My store was amazing to work at for 4 years. I worked in our petcare department and eventually managed it. The pets were always out first and taken to the vet if need be. Never had any problem getting them taken care of. Really depends on the management to set the mood for the store and thankfully mine was awesome. If i could have worked here the rest of my life i would have.

Company promises to train you and give you what you need. Gets by with with bare minimum training and then expects you to learn the rest on your own, while managing tasks, and by the way, staying overtime (which you then get in trouble for). Promises the moon, doesn't even deliver the stars.

This was my first job in retail, I needed some money and general experience, but the main reason why I quit 3 months into the job was mostly because I couldn't get my work schedule to work with my classes. I liked taking care of the animals and learning about them, and my co-workers were really pleasant folks to chat with and get to know and learn from. My main issue is mostly regarding the customers who obviously WILL NOT take proper care of the animals. I wished I had someone to back me up on certain issues. Like not selling a turtle to a customer who said that they were gonna stuff the thing in a one gallon tank (but then switched it around to 20 gallons when I told them that one gallon is the worst thing you could do to the thing, which is still unacceptable). It's one thing to deal with customers, phone calls, and product/service questons; but all of that with the care of the animals (feeding, cleaning, watering, making sure they're healthy, administering medicine, updating documents and sorting them out later, etc.) piled on top of that is just absurd for $9.25 an hour. :\

Its easy they have flexible schedule good pay for high school kids or second job or stay at home parents everyone is nice customers are great. I liked working there, the management is nice so are the employees if you like dogs you'll live working here.if u have a dog they give u a free dog training class, you get discounts to
I recommend PetSmart. It was a fun, enjoyable environment. Staff are generally happy. They have cute incentives for staff if you are doing well.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.
Not bad, but good for a first timer. The customers are usually friendly and understanding. The managers I had while working were horrible and had no idea what they were doing.

Working in the salon as a bather is super fun and rewarding- excellent part time work that is guaranteed to keep you in shape. But when they push you to be a groomer and then ask you to groom more and more dogs to make more money, it becomes way more stressful and way less fun. If you are a good groomer then you'll be fine. If you are more worried about dog safety and aren't confident in yourself, then I suggest going elsewhere. Petsmart, as a company, sees you as a cog, not as a person. It's also impossible to get time off during the holidays (seriously they won't allow you to). 50% commison or base pay for groomers. Have to meet sales goals and add on goals.

Grooming for a corporate owned grooming business just isn't worth it. They do have good health benefits and vacation time. No one really really appreciates being there though, causing a poor work environment
Hands down the *worst* place I ever worked. Worked in the grooming salon. We were always understaffed and overbooked or flat dead and had to work the store to get our hours.
Enjoyed being around animals. Most people were good to work with. Didn’t like being judged by customer reviews because people will complain and seldom give good reviews.
Temp job only. Corporate and managers give very little respect to animals and customers. Hire people to sell you product instead of how to truly care for you pet. Dog trainers are a joke.
Great place for a starter job in school to learn responsibility. Managers were friendly and helped me tremendously. They were aware and considerate of my school situation
A lot they drill into you is false information like nutrition. They cater to suck ups and allow rumors to spread. Expect to much if you're good and don't bother nagging if you're og lazy
It's hard to get full time and most of the workers are part timers only so not much benefits. You do get a discount on purchases made in store but thats about it.
I liked working for PetSmart but they didn't give me a raise even after two years. The managers were great but they all left at the same time so I did too

I like many other people turn 18 and immediately want to score a job at Petsmart. I would not recommend it if you are an animal lover, You are required to give sick animals medication without any type of training, when i asked for training on doing so, i was told to figure it out. Many of the animals that come in are sick, or have neurological issues, so this was an ongoing issue. You get trained for 1 day and are expected to know everything right off the bat, and are made to feel stupid by management when you ask how to do something.

I worked in the grooming salon. Clients were amazing, working with dogs was rewarding and a lot of fun. If you enjoy the dramas of middle school and the clicks that are there then this is the job for you! The supervisor talks about other employees with their co workers and makes the whole vibe feel like your working with a snarky high schooler, she also plays the pay back game if u miss a day she takes all ur requests and moves them off ur schedule. Very stressful and not very professional.

When I started the pay was sub par but expectable and staffing was alright if a bit thin. Since covid cooperate has cut hours and benefits reducing stores to less than a skeleton crew. Staff must dot he jobs of 3- 6 people is multiple departments at the same time. No overtime is allowed and non meal breaks are discouraged due to the lack of coverage. Most employees are so exhausted and overworked that burnout is inevitable. The environment is soul sucking, employees are punished for customer complaints when enforcing cooperate policy. Schedules come out 3-4 days before the next week if your lucky. Callouts are constant as well as no shows and you are expected to drop everything to cover.

Must stay on top of giving a good care of the pets & the pet parents . You're not only worrying about delivering service to pet's but also the pet parents who also make sure you're delivering excellent customer service to them .

I worked for Petsmart briefly as an order selector. Picking rate was difficult, and I had to work harder there to make rate than I had to work other places to earn bonus. For the workload and number of hours demanded, my base hourly rate was uncompetitive. Out PITs were old and poorly maintained to the point of sometimes being unsafe. Management cared about safety and employee welfare, but good management alone cannot overcome bad company policies.

My honest opinion is of you love animals and care about their well being regardless off the species this place is for you. The satisfaction you get from helping people on a daily basis is incredible. Nonetheless the knowledge you take away every day is mind blowing.

I worked at PetSmart with some of the smartest and hardest working people I've ever met. I started as a sales associate who also did early morning work stocking and transitioned into pet care later. Almost everyone I worked with shared the same goals of taking care of the animals, customers, and the store. Our store was perpetually understaffed, mostly due to a very high turnover rate and a lack of hiring. Assistant managers had high expectations but were understanding, while store management's expectations ran from punishing to ridiculous. Rarely were employees allowed to leave at their designated times, often staying 2+ hours past when their shifts were expected to end. A culture of fear developed wherein store and regional management were abusive towards assistant managers but outwardly kind to associates, which led to intense mistrust. I do know that since I worked there the manager I had has been fired, but only after every single employee at their new store collectively approached HR and threatened to quit. Local management is far from fully to blame for problems; corporate goals and policy shifted constantly. Obviously retail is a fast paced and ever changing environment, but expectations were already unrealistic. Adding huge store changes only served to make daily work impossible. One coworker would work every day, from open (4 AM) to well past close, sleep in their car, and do it all again, and were berated for not working hard enough regardless. My store was the highest volume store in our region, which may have influenced my experience, but unless substantial changes

I worked at two different locations at petsmart. Both locations were in Arizona. The first store I worked at was phenomenal. I had amazing managers and coworkers. However when I moved to the other store, everything changed. I felt like I was apart of one of the high school drama reality shows. From the moment I started working there, rumors were spread about me, there was constant drama between managers and employees. Managers really need to be more understanding of their employees, while also not playing favorites and taking only one person's story into account. A lot of the issues that played a big role had to do with management, but nobody ever wanted to complain due to potential retaliation.

It’s a fun job. I monitor over 20 dogs but I get to play with them, which is great. I clean up after the cats and dogs and bathe them. I love being around different breeds of dogs. I’m always learning something new everyday.
Fun place to learn. Good place for you 1st job. Good job for pet lovers. Friendly coworkers made job ez. Pay was sh**. but i would go back as a 2nd job.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

Everyone who works there is burnt out. The corporate office make decisions regardless of what’s best for us at our location, and there is no direct line of communication from my supervisor to corporate. Petsmart cares about profits, not their people.
Stressful but otherwise fun. Good training and pay but there were a lot of rude customers, maybe even more than working at a restaurant. But seeing animals would make it better.

The manager sucked and was the most judgmental and probably just shouldn’t have been a manager at all. I got worked way too much compared to everyone else and got paid very little for what I was doing. And I hear that from other previous bathers who worked at Petsmart at some point. Just not a good place to go. Find a mom and pop and you’ll learn so much more and be so much happier trust me.
Working in the pet hotel was hard work but the animals were great. Management could be rude sometimes but intolerable.
Terrible management and horrendous animal care management never scheduled enough people and tried to get coverage last minute. Hours were terrible. Either almost 40 hours or almost none at all.

Managers are great, was like a family there, except for the grooming salon. You feel like you have room to move up. Of course like any pet company you are sometimes forced to sell animals to people who will for sure neglect them and that sucks.

This was a good first job for me. Working part time when I was younger I was introduced to customer service, managing inventory, and general pet care. It’s retail so you get the boring days and the stressful days, the great customers and the terrible customers that’ll ruin your day. But overall it taught me a lot and was a good introduction to my professional career

I worked as a dog bather and the work wasn’t difficult but with the volume of dogs that come in that we have to bathe and groom, it can get very stressful. On top of that, I only got a 30 minute break that wasn’t exactly guaranteed everyday especially when the salon is booked and you’re getting phone calls and walk-ins all at once. Great manager and excellent coworkers made it bearable but the pay is just too low.
Petsmart Is a good place to start if you want to groom.

I worked in the doggie day care. You are in a room full of dogs by yourself for 5 hours at a time. It gets very boring and repetitive. You must love dogs to work in that department. It’s a good first job for young people but I wouldn’t recommend if you went to learn to learn new things. If you like a routine then stick to it.

Lots of hard work with very minimal help.  The managers are stuck in their own worlds and do not pay attention to their new employees who are still learning.  Management was hostile, and completely unfair.  Zero support and I personally felt very discriminated against.  Excellent employees, TERRIBLE management.
Very demanding and intense pressure to get sales. Always have to perform. The pet parents and animals were the best part of the job. Upset management could have been more supportive.

I worked in the Petshotel and while working with dogs everyday is fun there is also lots of stress for little pay. I'ts a great job if you plan on working there for a short time but you will burn out quickly if you work there for a while.

I worked front end and salon during my year of being at petsmart and it’s really cliquie, at least my store was,  don't get me wrong I liked working for petsmart but sometimes you didn’t feel valued for the work you do.

Management was on our backs constantly about performance numbers in the grooming salon and expected us to get huge or misbehaving dogs out in less than 2 hours. Other groomers gossiped behind your backs. Loved working with the dogs though.

I been working at PetSmart for over a year as a Pet Stylist. I came with experienced which was a $500 sign in bonus which was nice,  at first they said I would start as part time and then move up to full time, that never happened and everytime I asked about it Manager gaved an excuse or said I had to improve some stuff, as time went by I improved what they asked of me but they still wouldnt give me the full time, the customers that show up at the store where very mean and rude towards the employs as customers are entilted,  the environment is fast paced and very stressful with loud noise in the background the dogs are always scared of coming in even if we try to calm them down its not possible with all the noise from the backroom where they dry the dogs. The bathing area is filled with mold and it stinks and I would tell them it needs to be clean with clorox or some other product to get rid of mold and Managers dont listen to you.
Managers mingle with employees and sometimes date, even against policy.  I quit because of this reason.  No room for advanvement.  They want want want, but dont care if your ok in life.

Although the job itself is very tiring and very much a retail job, the pets and their parents make the everyday drag fun and something to look forward to. I didn't have much support from my upper management when it came toward the end of my time at the company, but my co-workers were lovely. I did watch multiple quick and what I felt were unnecessary changes in the staff, along with being passed over for a promotion for an outside despite being totally qualified for the position. If you're looking to spend YEARS trying to get to where you want to go in the company, maybe this is the right place for you.

I was given very little explanation on what my duties would be and how to operate the cash register. A few of the Managers were frustrating to work with. They frequently sound inconsiderate.  The job was easy enough and some what relaxing butt as time went on it felt more and more unfulfilling.

I love working my job. I just feel like it could be better. Management needs to improve. Treat people right and just maybe employees would stay longer. I know I don’t like to job hop around. I guess that’s why I’ve been here so long (off and on)

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

I worked here as a college job for several years. The people I worked with were lovely, but upper management saw us as expendable, basically. Harassment by customers was virtually ignored and we were continually understaffed, meaning lots of double shifts and having to come in on your day off. Zero employee appreciation, scheduling vacation was difficult and you were guilt tripped frequently. I would not recommend working here.

If you’re exposed to COVID 19, then they want you to get a Covid test before returning to work. HOWEVER, they don’t want to foot the bill. Earning less than $10, including all the bills that I still have to pay, on top of a Covid test being $600, I couldn’t pay it, and they refuse to. This company hasn’t ever cared about their employees. They just want warm bodies to fill their store.

PetSmart is a great job on paper and everyone seems friendly on paper but at the end of the day it is still retail. You are running to a lot of the same nonsense however if you have a great store/salon manager, you'll do fine. Its still one of my favorite jobs and it is a great company

It was a terrible place to work. Nothing but people who didn’t care and had nothing to say to you. People would ignore you all the time and offer no help. But if you don’t help someone else when it is busy, it is the end of the world. Terrible job. Everyone pretends to be nice and is just rude.

It's a corporate company so just like any company it has its good things and it's bad things. You like working there or you won't.  You never know what you're going to get from store to store you don't know if there's going to be any consistency.

They were not accommodating with my schedule, I worked there for 7 years in the grooming salon. Management treated us like we were red-headed stepchildren. This includes my store manager and district manager. I had such high hopes for pet smart. I thought they were a good company. I did not like how other groomers treated the dogs jerking them around and it was just sad.

This was such a fun job. I worked with the animals and helped people out who needed help with their pet needs. Management and coworkers were nice. Sometimes cleaning the animal habitats was super tiring but other than that it was fun. Can’t complain much.

Overall, as a manager. It wasn't a bad company. It was fun, every day was different. At the time I was there, they micromanaged and nitpicked some things, but they may have eased up since going back to private vs public. There were a few store manager changes in my time, and that was really what made or broke your time there. My one manager was extremely supportive and made the store fun. A newer manager made it a miserable tight ship where you did no right. The pay for the amount of work and time could have been better.
Forced Overtime and they push you about numbers when everyone is to tired from the Overtime to be productive. Used to be a fun place to work before covid

Good pay but draining. You have a robot in your ear that tells you what to do and you do it. There is no difference in your days. You line up to clock in, get in your pallet rider, and go where the robot says. The boxes you need to put single pieces in will all disappear after break. The slip sheets disappear. And you're on a time limit. It's not hard, it's just numbing. You'll spend your days off dreading coming back.

Good luck moving forward in this company without cross training into more than 3 departments and also moving stores. The goal of this place is to drain you of as much as it can before you give out and quit so it can hire jn the next victim. Multiple promises if promotions, raises, more hours but none of it ever came.

I worked my way up from a part-time employee to a full-time leader position. I did what was required of me at all times, even went above and beyond to help cover extra shifts when associates call out or don’t show up to their scheduled shifts. Some days I worked 12+ hour shifts in order to help out “the pack.” You’re constantly told you’re doing a great job and that you’re an excellent addition to the team. Except when it’s inconvenient for the team. Constant drama and bickering amongst the employees. I have a degree but unfortunately petsmart pays me more than working in my actual field of study. I’ve tried to mention to management that I’d like to move up to a corporate level position, seeing that I feel that I’m ready for it. But I’m told I’m “too young” and that I’m perfectly fine where I’m at. No opportunities to move up within the company. I don’t want to be a leader for 25+ years before being considered for a corporate level position. Everything is great and you have an advantage, until you decide to have a family. Schedule is limited and management becomes upset if you can’t respond to emergency incidents or help cover a shift if somebody calls out. Management is always micro-managing what you do, they don’t let you run your department without some sort of negative input. You can’t hire employees without consulting with the district leader first. It’s an extremely stressful company to work for, if you’re at the retail level. Management also takes your words and twists them to better fit their stories, putting you at risk of losing your job. Also, if you try to call out

Petsmart as a company is a decent company to work for. They offer great benefits and try to offer incentive to employees by offering little snacks in the break room. The store management is where the company issues lie. They don't follow through with maintaining a fair work environment. They work the hard workers past their limits and let the slackers slide on by. There is absolutely no drive to continue to work hard because they don't encourage it.
i liked working here a lot but had to quit when i moved. it’s a great starter job, working as a cashier. you really get to know your regular customers and it definitely fosters a sense of community.

Unless the store goes under new management, do not work here. Management doesn't care about you. No one is ever written up or fired, the work environment is toxic and abusive, if anything is broken it takes months to fix or they slap a patch on it, and management doesn't follow the rules set by corporate (especially if it's an inconvenience to themselves).
The pickiest realm of retail there is....animals and people's pets. Drives you nuts. The pay is horrible. Management doesn't stick around. Customers are the worst
Not much good coming from this company as a whole. Just a pay check for most til they can find other work.

I enjoyed helping customers seek the best products for their pets and also selling their pets to them. I also enjoyed caring for all the fish, reptiles and small mammals but corporate will only do so much for them veterinary care wise which is sad.

If you deeply care about animals, this is not the place for you. The company only cares about money but they constantly claim how much they care about the animals for sale in the store. Yet they force us to house too many animals together, sell them to anyone, and provide less than basic care to them. If you try to change anything for the better, even if you are using your own money (for fresh vegetables for the animals for example) you will immediately be shut down. Not to mention the pay is garbage and loyalty means nothing to them. Animal retail is a very dark place and not a good fit for anyone who struggles with depression and/or really loves animals.

Most stores are really understaffed, you only get benefits if you're management. Most of your opinions or thoughts on improving the store go unheard or they listen and tell you it is a great idea then never implement any of your suggestions. The petcare department is completely overworked and under appreciated. The distribution center never has supplies we need to run the store.. There has been no really safety PPE rules for customers during COVID. We are not allowed to make them wear a mask only suggest it. Basically if you like just working for a paycheck this job isn't for you. Instead of coming to work and doing just your job you end up doing other people's work on top of your own responsibilities.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

I have heard that it depends on your salon and they can be very cliquey. I am lucky to have great coworkers but management can be iffy and they have cut my hours before without warning or explanation. Working in the salon can also be stressful as dogs can be unpredictable and basically if they aren't aggressive at check in we are expected to take them. You can always choose to send a dog home if you aren't comfortable but sometimes you feel judged by management for doing so.
Very unorganized. You will have three managers all tell you to do something different. You can’t do three things at once they will get mad at you for not doing all of the tasks at once.

The fact that the management knew nothing about the animals and their care, along with how poorly they treated the employees that actually knew what they were doing was insane. There was a lack of communication and a clear difference in treatment of employees, they pick favorites. They do not allow you to call off for anything and instead demand you find replacements for your shift but will still mark you as a no call no show.
Petsmart has a way of taking a job that should be rewarding and fun and turning it into work that has you crying in your car on the commute to and from your store location.
It get fairly busy most of the day, I feel overwhelmed and overworked by being the only cashier in the area. Coworkers don’t help, they just stand around and talk.

I was excited to work at Petsmart as I love animals and would go there often to just hang out and look at the pets for sale. After extensive online training I was thrown onto the register since I had cashier experience. It was fairly easy to learn how everything worked there but the register systems are pretty old. There is rarely anyone working on the floor, it’s usually only a manager, a cashier, and a pet care associate. Extensive organizing and cleaning at the end of night and morning stockers have to be there at 4am even if it is very cold or snowing

I have been at Petsmart since November 2012 and have never enjoyed working at a place as much as here. The management has been great, the people I have worked with have been great and most of the customers are great as well.  Im always encouraged, feel important and feel like i make a difference in the company. I have fun at my job I love love love being there.

People who were tenured were being paid less than new hires. It was unfair and the managers won't budge on money, not least when I worked there. They also would change the schedule and not let associates know. I also would come in 22-28 pallet trucks and told to finish it in 8 hours, when it was technically supposed to take 1 hour per pallet.

Management is horrible, all they care about is how much money you make, always short staffed especially in the salon. Been working here for 2 years and would’ve quit by now if they hadn’t forced me to go to academy and sign a 2 year contract

Co-workers are awesome. Managers are alright. They go through them quick there, so don't get attached. Don't get too attached to your job, either, because you'll be moved around the store to different parts whether you like it or not. I was Pet Care. But I was barely ever in that department by the time I left. I was cashiering, stocking, inventory, customer service. You do not get paid extra to use your own car to take animals to the vet. You do not get a company vehicle to take them either. Management pays you as little as possible for as much work as possible. Variable hours, too. One week I would work 35 hours, the next 14. No consistency. No say on holidays. No bonuses.
Could have been an okay place to work, if not for management. Was told to stop helping customers so much. Favoritism runs very high in the company. Its an okay place to work, but not long term.

worked there for four years and never got to advance past associate lead. you don’t have much say over the animals in your care and can’t deny people animals unless they specifically say they plan to feed a hamster to a snake and even then depending on the manger they may say it’s okay

I was a groomer at Petsmart and would have stayed for years if I didn’t have to leave due to personal medical complications. The management at my store was great, always encouraging and helpful. My co-workers in the salon were all very nice. We were a team, and everyone helped each other when needed. There was also plenty of opportunities for growth.

Management Is horrible. I was hired as a seasonal worker but was told seasonal workers always end up being permanent. I called in to get my schedule one week and they said “oh you’re no longer working here” super unprofessional’
Management, especially above the store level cares much more about their numbers on their scoreboard than animal or employee health.  They did pay decent with great benefits.
No words, I honestly loved working with the pets and coworkers were really respectful and friendly. Pay was ok can't complain at all. Take the job if you feel it best suit you.
Pay is terrible for the amount of work you have to do. Injuries are very likely. The pets are wonderful and make the job enjoyable, but after so long it’s too stressful. Too understaffed.

My experience at PetSmart. The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive. The schedule is flexible. I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful. the management encourages employee success. The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer. I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at. The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

Working in the petsmart grooming salon it was very isolated compared to the rest of the store which was both good and bad, but in the end there was always drama, and with so few people in the salon it was rough being dragged into it a lot of the time.

Although they gave good hours, the management was horrible and condescending. They were not flexible with the fact that I am a college student and many employees that had been there a long time left during my short time there due to the rude manager. I had to leave due to their inflexibility with my college schedule even though they knew I was a college student when they hired me. They don't want you to leave the cash wrap even when there is no one there and you will get yelled at if you do. Definitely do not work here, it is not worth it.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.
Was a groomer for 5 years. Wasnt a bad job as long as I kept my head down, made lots of money and didnt question anything. Not a lot of room for growth and can be a very drama filled workplace.
Overall good. Standard retail job. Customers tend to be pretty understanding. Corporate makes things hard when they leave you short staffed. For a retail job it's great

I was employed for 13 yrs. with PetSmart. I loved my co-workers, my clients and my dogs! Only negative is no support from management. They promise to help you out, but don't. No discipline for people who do wrong, weekly.
This was a great job for me I was retired.  I enjoyed the pet parents and seeing all the pets come in.  There is room for advancement and they take the time to train you.
This job is pretty chill.  A lot of regular customers.  Co-workers are all pretty nice.  It gets boring sometimes when it’s slow.  The pay isn’t that much.

Seems like you go through a lot of managers. You either get ones that care about you or ones that want you out the door. The ones who don’t care will make you feel like you’re walking on eggshells. As a groomer, cutting a dog is something that can easily be done especially if you’re new and still learning. But they’ll over look that and make you feel like you are about to be dropped. Tell you things like “maybe pick a different career” You seem to get criticized more for your mistakes than what goals you’ve actually accomplished along the way. I wish there was more of a way to express your concerns to the district manager without having to go through your store manager which is who I have the most problems with.
Company provides you with ample amount opportunities given you put in the effort. Fast paced with the best past is getting to meet the animals and to get to know their pet parents

I interviewed for a petcare/customer service associate position. Management told me I would be trained in both then move into the grooming salon as a dog bather. All of my shifts for the last four months (out of the 8 months I have been employed at petsmart) have been cashier. I have not had the opportunity to gain the necessary knowledge I need to successfully carry out all duties pertaining to the petcare position. Therefore I have not had the opportunity to progress into the grooming salon. Management has been made aware of the situation and has been very slow to remedy.
This place has way more downs than ups. Upper management is pretty much a joke at most stores, and when you try to tell the person above that, you get dismissed.
