It's alright. You get to work with some pretty cool people. Management is.. questionable. Your work is never really appreciated, more expected than anything. Doesn't give you a sense of motivation. If you raise the bar one week, you're expected to work at that level afterwards. If not, questions will  be asked. The team working inventory basically run the store. They do about 90% of everything that goes on. Props to the inventory manager for taking 99% of the heat for any little thing wrong with the store.
Some drama but that’s to be expected. 99% of the team is amazing and supportive. I work half in the grooming salon and half on the floor. Each side has its pros and cons.

As a bather/cashier it was a relaxed and fun environment to work in. It could get stressful when it got busy and there was a lack of other bathers but overall it was a chill job.  Didn't like the drama though from all other employees.

I loved getting to see the different pets and pet parents that came through our doors everyday. Learning new facts about animals was so much fun. Work was not very difficult. Sometimes you would be asked to do more than normal but you didn't always have to. My co-workers were very friendly and nice. The biggest problem PetSmart has is its company attendance policy. You get 3 absences per year and that's it. Pets dies? Well they may love pets, but not yours and still expect you to show up in a great mood. Get Covid-19 symptoms, which they instruct you not to come in if you have? That's not counted either. They wouldn't even write down what your excused absences were, so I never knew what were ones they should have considered excused and which ones were not. After 3 absences every absence is a strike. 3 strikes you're out. The expectations are ridiculous. Its okay for a short time but if you have sick family or struggles yourself, don't expect to stay long. Oh and they only send you to the bathroom on break.

Worked with good managers for most of my time. Then when the company was taken private and sold, they sucked the life out of good people. The demands became unachievable and morale suffered irrevocably. Pay was taken away (managers going from 45 to 40 hours within their store). Bonuses went away because goals were unattainable. All they did was pay off execs  and remodel after remodel. Stopped investing time and money into the amazing people they had in stores.
This is a dead end position. Management is unhelpful and there is no challenge or growth opportunity. It is fun being able to meet all the pets that come by
Good place to work to learn how to become a groomer. Free training and ability to make good money.  Although there is a contract to sign.  It’s okay.

Working there was completely awful. I was promised a promotion that was given to someone else. I felt very underpaid for my work load. I had covid in December /January of 2019/2020 and they made me work even though I had a doctors note excusing me from work
Store manager is absolutely amazing! I honestly don't think I will EVER have a better boss; the assistant store manager on the other hand, is why I no longer work here.

Managers are very manipulative and disrespectful. While I was working there, I got sick and had doctors notes exempting me from certain things and management didn’t abide to the drs notes. I was diagnosed with cancer and when I let my management know, one laughed and said I was making it up to get out of work.

Your experience heavily depends on your management.  There were highs and lows based on the higher ups. If you have a supportive manager and team, you have the potential to have a great experience with upward mobility to a point.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

Worked as a dog bather the managers and cooperate did not care about their employees all they cared about was how many dogs you can groom and how fast so they can get their bonuses. Which is not safe for dogs or the employees.

I liked most of the people I worked with. Managment definitely plays favorites. The company doesnt really care for employees or animals. You dont need to know anything to work there and employees constantly have false information on animals. After covid started they fired our cleaner so we had nobody to clean the store. The company only cares about money.

It is a productive, heavy work store. But you always see beautiful  animals so the time flies there when you’re working, Helping customer all the time is so nice... What I didn’t like is the management cause didn’t Appreciate it all the hard work that you do to have the store nice.. They didn’t give me any compensation for 14 years of hard work
I do enjoy working at Petsmart, and have learned a lot while working here. I do wish there was more communication between management, and compensation needs to improve with all associates.

Petsmart takes great care of the animals there, but all the training is on computer and there is little on the job training. You just have to figure it out as you go along. Day Camp feels like you're in there to entertain the people watching you rather than take care of and entertain the dogs in Day Camp. They also have a really hard time firing bad workers and the management has no accountability for when they're doing their job poorly.

Never seemed to have enough people to work a truck. People always called in forcing you to pick up their slack. Management never has enough hours to go around so they have to work us like mules to finish assignments.

Very toxic work environment, I wasn’t paid enough to do the store managers,assistant store managers job and the mils jobs and not being able to do my cel position. Constantly was degraded in-front of customers because I couldn’t find time to get my job done while trying to do everyone else’s. Always walked on egg shells because I never knew what mood the store manager was going to walk into the store with.
The animals are probably the best part about this job, I worked here for almost a year as a cashier/pet care associate and its your typical retail store.
I was excited to work with pets. But it turns out, i was on graveyard as a janitor with no interaction with the pets. Cleaning all play areas, surrounding areas.

You get more hours the more you try and follow policies put in place. There can be a downside with dealing with the customer side of things since it is a retail environment. Customers can be hard to work with especially during this current pandemic, and the store is not given enough hours to help accommodate for curbside pick up. Sometimes there will be only one person on the floor with a cashier who isn’t able to really help out much so one person can be stuck doing curbsides, animal department work, stocking, and prepping the store which can be very overwhelming on a busy day. A lot of the customers will anticipate quick services when there is a skeleton crew and end up harassing the workers due to lack of staffing.

I worked at Petsmart for a few years and enjoyed my team because we all were supportive of giving animals the best treatment. When I pursued management, I was not allowed an opportunity to advance, or even told what I needed to work on to get there. Good job for a college student, or for temporary work as it can be a struggle at times but overall fun if you’re not in too deep
Greeting pet parents and their pets and trying to form bonds with them would have been the best part of the job had we not been in the middle of a pandemic.
At the particular Petsmart I was employed at it was very nice and professional work environment. Management deserve to be treated better given the district manager gives unrealistic goals often.

The grooming salon is a fun place to work however it does get overwhelming and there are a lot of demands from the company. Very hard to find time for lunches and breaks on the weekends. It is mostly about the money but if you make it fun and have good coworkers it is a great job.

It really depends on what management is like in the store. I worked at one store where managers cared and worked WITH their team. Animal care was fantastic, shelves were clean and stocked, grooming was run well and safely. I’ve also worked at other stores where animals were sick and dying left and right because staff didn’t care and management didn’t care or follow up, shelves were disorganized, planners were months behind, food on shelves was expired/recalled but left out for weeks, tanks had more dead than alive fish, and management did nothing about it

Top manager was terrible! People would call out left and right with no repercussions and I would have to work extra & pick up the slack! Hours were cut without warning if the manager making the schedule didn’t like you or thought you weren’t a good worker. Overall terrible experience, I only stayed because I needed the money & didn’t want to go through a lot of interview processes. The pay was also average and unfair some people made less than others just because they didn’t speak up about pay at the interview.
If your in school then it’s good, but if your looking for money and a long term job then no? Great with school and you do learn a lot about some animals, I learned a lot from customers experiences

Corporate expects one person to complete the workload of three people. Management in the store was great, but under a lot of pressure to meet deadlines and increase productivity with no staff. They're more concerned with silly catchphrases and metrics than keeping shelves stocked. I moved on due to lack of opportunity for advancement and no training provided for the role I was in. As a store that sells animals, they do take excellent care of the animals and the people that work there truly love pets.
lots of walk ins and phone call disruptions, can get really hectic during the weekend, some dogs are very dangerous but some days are relaxing and calm with well behaved dogs.

Great work environment and good rotations on schedules at my location. Pet care is the better position in my opinion.  Learned a lot about animals, how to care for them, and what brands are healthy for the specific pet. You learn as you go through you job meaning you don't have to know everything about animals you learn by asking questions, observing coworkers help other pet parents, and reading the brochures.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

Depending on which Petsmart you work at, you can expect that your supervisors won't help you out when needed. Most of the time I did independent work which was fine but they had a hard time working with my schedule as a student. When I wanted more hours during COVID, they neglected me.

People care about you and your family at the PetSmart DC.  Paid time off, pay for performance, and leaders who build relationships with their teams.  There is work to be done for sure and 100% is expected, but the atmosphere is such that your team and supervision help us to succeed in your daily work and balancing stuff going on outside work.  Plus, business has been growing lately so plenty of opportunities.

Liked working here a lot just make sure you get a good location some managers treat you better than others just make sure your on time and if your stocking don’t let them make you do it alone or you will burn out fast supposed to be a team effort find them puting a lot of responsibility on new employees not always fair

I had a terrible onboarding process and very rude boss that didn't take the time to train me at the corporate office. Please be sure you really feel a good vibe towards your direct corporate direct report.
Management was always so understanding and working with the animals was a lot of fun. I was laid off due to covid-19 otherwise i would still be working there. Very friendly environment
Nothing special.  It was a job.  Average warehouse/ distribution center.  Don't expect to much from them and they don't eclectic to much in return.  Decent
Management doesn't care about you. You are under payed and unappreciated. Lazy employees. No benefits at all.

Been working for PetSmart for only a few weeks now, at first it was fun. I enjoyed learning new things about the company but I was just thrown in without any real training. I trained for about an hour and then was thrown into a shift to cover for someone else. Management was okay but did not take into consideration the max number of hours I said I could work.
I hated working here, they wouldn’t even let you use the bathroom.  Management disappears for hours, it takes them forever to show up if a customer wants to talk to them.

Things were never amazing at Petsmart, but the company really dropped the ball the last year or so. We never received hazard pay, our bonus for giving them their "best year ever in sales" was $275 BEFORE they taxed it, and they failed to hire on enough people to get the work done. We've been mandated each week, working 50-60 hours since about July. Management only cares about their own bonuses and about moving up; you're completely disposable. Look at all the orange vests on the floor (new hires) and you'll see proof of the turnover rate there.

I loved working here. Decent pay, cross training available and there are always opportunities to advance in the company. The entire staff is very easy to get along with and all have very good morals and we all worked as a team, it didn't all fall on one employee. I rarely had a difficult customer. I would still be there if it weren't for my health issues and the COVID pandemic.
A good start to a day always turned bad at Casselberry location, payroll wasn’t entered correctly more than multiple times.. great company! Poor management! Period!
I call this my therapy and you get too meet alot of people and their pets.  Great people to work with as well.  You get discounts on the products and in grooming.  The vets are great as well.

Recently, my mom was in the hospital (the icu) and I needed off. They wouldn’t let me have the day off. They say they care for their associates but they don’t. I worked in the grooming salon and everyone except for my salon leader, who was guilt tripped into stepping down, was always talking about me behind my back but never confronted me to my face. Management is terrible. Overall work environment is very toxic. I loved my job, just not the people I worked with. I will never again work for petsmart. Definitely not worth the stress everyday for how little you get paid.
It was O.K. I feel the pay should be more. You do not get enough time to clean up and restock at the end. I did not like how on my break I would be sometimes called back to help!

I absolutely loved being able to help care for and learn more about how to care for pets, what is required and recommended for care of pets, as well as learning about how to best help customers and teach customers the best way to care for a family companion. Some of the associates and managers hired can be iffy, but staff can also be amazing.

They don't care about the animals or employees, only the bottom line and HR is the biggest joke I've ever dealt with. Written up for doing my job and what was asked of me twice. This place is not good.
Fun job it was a good time. Good job for the summer before college, I enjoyed the people I worked with along with the flexible hours that were available.

Management is poor with this company, lack of communication. No one seems to be on the same page. There is not an opportunity for growth for a career, as they tell you in the beginning when you start. I was top performer and was never considered for promotions.

The work is incredibly taxing on the body. They don't want you to sit while on your shift, which is 8 hours or more. You have to be able to lift and handle heavy dogs so it's tiring work. However, I'd rather be interacting with the dogs than the customers, so it's good for that. The pay is less than I'd like for the amount of stress you're put under.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

Working as a pet groomer for 5 years. Seen all types of management through this place and it is run horribly. Never expect to have a manager have your back or if you need something within reason it will not get done. Job security is not secure. If you cutt more than three dogs a year you are fired. This goes for new, trainee groomers as well and it always makes you feel like you are walking on eggshells shells. Not saying cutting a dog is not a big deal because it is, but accidents happen.

Pets are the best aspect. The associates will form clicks and if they don’t like you the new associate on the team, they make life miserable for that associate until they quit or get fired. The associates go out of their way to not work. They are rude to customers and can’t comply with simple requests like greeting all customers. They act like they are the all knowing authority on pets, and refuse to sell pets to customers.

Loved loved my management and coworkers. I just got really stressed with the work of being a dog groomer and balancing meeting customers needs. As we all know the customer is not always right and sometimes it gets hard to swallow that differing opinion. I also began to feel more uncomfortable and stressed working retail during this pandemic even though the company tried their best to figure out regulations.

The management often can be super stressy, which puts pressure on all of us who work in the salon. You're pushed to groom as many dogs possible, even if that affects the quality of the groom you do, or if you push the dog's stress level.

Not a bad place to work but you need to have compassion for animals that they sell and/or adopt.  If you're not an animal lover it could affect how you feel about working there.  Groomers need to be compensated mores.

I worked in the PetsHotel as an Associate Lead and our direct Hotel Leader was AMAZING and I loved the team I worked with. However the rest of management was very lacking. There was little reward for going above and beyond (which I did regularly, staying late into the night with sick pets at the vet), but we were very heavily reprimanded for anything we did wrong. Plus there was imbalance in pay. I found out that there were some Associates being paid the same as the Leads, when as Leads we not only did the same work as them but also much more. The store manager also regularly made us feel like our jobs were at risk, and while we tried to be there for the pets it very quickly became apparent that PetsMart cared more about making sure they weren’t losing money and making sure their policies were strictly followed, even if it meant endangering a pet’s life or risking them getting sick. It hurt too much for me to continue working there as I have a great passion for animals and I hated not being able to give them the care that they deserved.

I worked as a seasonal Pet Care Associate, and although your experience will vary from location to location and manager to manager, I absolutely loved my time there. If the pay was better/I had been able to advance within the company I would've have stayed a good while longer. Coworkers were crazy fun, management was really patient and helpful. Awesome job for a summer worker or college student.

Solid company and I had a fantastic district leader who led with respect and professionalism. It can be a tough place to work and they often don't have the answers you need to meet expectations but given the retail circumstances its a good place to work.
Pay is good as well as a lot of overtime. Room to move within the company and flexible shifts. It’s extremely labor intensive and you are held to a production standard based on a rate system.

Most store managers are lazy and if you do a good job they want to keep you in that job and don’t want to give you an opportunity to succeed and move further in your career it’s all about what they can do to keep you in your spot so they can be lazy and sit in the office all day and blame all the issues on all the employees and take no responsibility themselves for anything

This job never cares about the employees only about how many hours they can give you without breaking you. They never give you time off. All you do is clean up animal .... and get paid horribly for it

The best part of my job is the interactions that i have with customers pets. Engaging with them and watching them grow is special. Even though work is stressful and most customers are not nice, the pets get me through the day.
Enjoyed the work and seeing animals daily. Not much support from other employees though. Some coworkers had attitudes while others were nice. Not the worst job.

Covid showed PetSmart's corporate office's true colors. They slashed hours even after seeing a stable increase in revenue during these times. They laid off loyal employees of 15+ years. Customer Service managers are often times stuck on the registers for 2-3 shifts a week due to not having hours for cashiers. Merchandising managers are working trucks completely alone so that their stocking hours can be used in the live animal department and registers.

Management is okay, except for two people you won't be able to stand, barely any hours, every day I walked in my anxiety shot through the roof because of the work environment. If it gets busy at the register, and you aren't somehow magically working freight with 5 customers in line at the same time then you get yelled at. I was switching to new meds and was yawning a lot cuz of the meds, our store leader got mad at me for YAWNING in front of a customer. We weren't allowed to discuss wages with fellow employees so they could pay unfairly.

When i worked first two years where good the last was horrible they changed management and it all went down. Not only did 1/2 the staff quite the cleanliness was lacking and the dogs where hurt by it. I hope it has bettered by now.

Here's a tip, if you do want to work for PetSmart make a manager your friend. Otherwise YOU WILL NEVER GET PROMOTED. we have a stocker who routinely works triple what the stocking team does ( four other people) put together and instead of recognizing the hard work he's done over the years they promote a manager's buddy. Don't work here unless you absolutely need the money.

Started out as an orderfill employee. Basic training is given and is sufficient for the job. You are trained on an electric pallet jack with the standard headset for picking. Performance goals are easy to meet even when you talk to coworkers from time to time. Advancement to other positions are given to those who show hard work. My time there was enjoyable as I did my work and was still able to have a great work/home life balance.
Coworkers always awesome and the pets. Management and cooperate is terrible! There care more for the $$ then the pets and employees. They allow customers to railroad the employees all the time.

They pay you nothing as the next person through the door gets more than you. You get written up for having a disability. Management is a revolving door. Requiring base peon employees to do every job in the store at any given time without training. Push you to move to another store without place to live or transportation or $

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

This company is awesome. They have helped me with a lot in my personal life. They care about you and your wellbeing. They love pets and pet parents. They try to help associates and customers as best as they can.

While the customers were always a bit of an issue, as they seemed to think they knew more than the professional groomers, nothing was as bad as the management in my old store. When I transferred, the manager was perfectly accommodating and the most helpful I think she could have possibly been, but my first location had someone who was completely useless at her job.

Management was ok but could do much better with how they handled workers. Couldn't maintain them and had one employee rampage the store. Other than that not a terrible place to work in an interim situation.

Its a retail job, you're just a body until you move up, if you can move up. Then maybe you get a little more known, but you're still disposable. Ultimatly this is the nature of the beast that is retail, bottom line is everything. What makes it bearable are those you work with day to day.

The co-workers were really nice and likable, and the discounts are definitely a plus but in the end that's about it. Training is very minimal so you kind of have to teach yourself or spend a lot of time running back and forth asking questions. There are definitely too many chiefs and not enough indians. On top of that the company rules are also a bit rediculous, and you can tell the higher ups don't have ANY real knowledge on animals what so ever. Its a good job if you're in a pinch and don't plan on staying long. During the pandemic I barely worked 8 hours one week and was one of the only employees to actually receive hours. On top of that days off mean practically NOTHING since you'll probably just get called in anyway so your personal life is pretty much out the window. Its not the worst place to work but not exactly the best.
I love working with animals and the people in my direct department, however pet parents have so much leverage even though they don’t know store policy
Hardest part of the job....... and the management. What you learn and how to get through each day. Keep your head high and push through its all worth it.

Petsmart is a good place to work. You have the ability to move uo in the company. However, their care for the animals they sell is very lax. The store I worked at didn't train very well. I was mostly thrown to the wolves in hopes I'd survive. They would answer any questions I had, but for the most part, I was on my own. Their "care sheets" for the animals are more for the company's pockets than the welfare of the animals. Their pet care manual for the animals does not line up with the care the animals actually need. HR will fire you in the blink of an eye for any reason they want. The customer is ALWAYS right (even when they're harassing you, you can't defend yourself)

The Hours were good.  The Management was great.  The Customers were fun.  Every thing about Petsmart was good.  A place anyone could be proud to work at.  I had family issues that I had to address and had to quit.
Management is terrible and doesn’t care about you. Salon is filled with toxic people. If you care about your mental health save yourself the trouble.
Avoid  the call center.  Manager don't do much to help  you grow. They micro manage you all the time. QA is very nit pickey and a joke.  People  are on right ups all the time.

i worked for the company many years and it was only when the company sold was when it went down hill. cut jobs, put more work on leaders. animals get neglected because "customers are more important". some managers are dictators. health insurance went to garbage. overall company doesnt care about the associates or the animals. just making money

Working in the salon you never get time to take your breaks, always leaving at least an hour late due to constantly being overbooked. Constant drama in the workplace it is like being in highschool again. Constant negative energy from clients about prices and corporate rules that i have no control over. Just extremely exhausting and makes me hate my job when i always used to love it. depressing.

Worked there for 4 straight years worked extremely hard to be good at what I do. I helped fulfill the sales plan for management so they could get their precious bonuses and was fired for bringing my personal dog to work.  When it's in or policy we can bring our own dogs, therefore,  the higher ups do not care about you they don't care to hear an explanation "I don't think you're being very truthfull" is what I was told.  Pay is good if you can upsell and from 8vdogs a day just mind your business perform the groom or bathe the dogs and everything should be good.

The company became money hungry and began to care about their huge profits rather than the pets and people who provided their income. The culture devoloped a lie based refusal to accept responsibility.
You will be treated unfairly. Production standard continually climbed to near impossible quotas. Bathroom breaks were even timed. Lifting heavy products all day.

Worked there for about a year. They force you to stay over time. Understaffed. Work you like a dog for minimum wage. You also have to pick up dog feces all the time and the base staff is very competitive. Also, they make you work in pet care and answer questions you know nothing about.

I worked on the cashier and did stocking sometimes. Pretty cool, can get busy but nothing I couldn't handle. Nice working around different pets all day. One customer even came in with a little finger monkey!

Job was okay. But, you can tell from the import of animals through trucks that they were not well taken care of. They come from large factory breeding facilities. They may care about dogs/cats, but they do NOT care about any other animals. Profits>animals.

You do so much besides grooming which can be extremely stressful and your a number not an individual.  You answer phones, make report cards before covid,  make appointments, check in and out dogs which may be other people's,  clean, wash your dog,  and groom. Oh but focus on dog and be safe.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

Was incredibly underpaid for the work that I did. Managers weren't the best and didnt care. They schedule you outside of your availability and if the manager is mad at you for something they will purposely not schedule you for weeks on end. They have major favoritism amongst employees. You only get a 10% discount. Short breaks and no employee appreciation.
Enjoyed most of my time there. I work there years ago as a Pet care manager and enjoyed what I did. Management team was overall really good.  Dm's always kept amagement in edge.

Horrible  just too long to write no one got permitted within the grooming department it ALLWAYS came from a different location ALLWAYS people applying and getting the job and quitting  so we had to train every new never getting a raise or anything they wouldn’t take you take time off of you had a child that was sick and poor management

they drive out their good employees by working them to the bone and promising them opportunities for advancements that never come. since covid they have also drastically cut hours while piling work onto the remaining associates, management is breathing down your neck while offering zero pay incentive for doing the job of 3 people. horrible communication skills with management and they gossip about the associates they are supposed to be leading. the people that do get promoted are either a byproduct of playing favorites or an outside hire. After 5 years I have lost all respect for this place.

I greatly enjoyed my time working at PetSmart. The wide variety of dogs that I got to work on was always fun as I am a bit of a sucker for animals anyhow. The only thing that drove me away from this job is because you do not get paid enough in my position as a bather to compensate for the hard work that it is. You always risk getting bit by the dogs, the work is physically demanding as there is no time to sit and you often have to lean over dogs to work with them your entire shift. The way you feel after you work varies wildly as somedays you may get all dogs that are well behaved and very patient and other times you may get large dogs that want to bite or fight with you, and thus you leave very exhausted. Customer service is a forefront in the Bathers position as you must welcome customers into the salon then carry out a list of procedures such as checking over the dog for overall health. I am the type of person to enjoy a lot of new and exciting things in a job so as not to get bored, so this job was very enjoyable in that regard. If you really like to keep busy, this is a job for you.

Getting back into working after kids, I was glad to get a chance.  I loved getting  to know our return customers/pet parents, I had a great work team & my supervisors were  wonderful.  Experiences will be based on location!!
It's retail, and all retail is hard but working with management and "animal people" is another ballgame. People that spend 65 dollars for 20 pounds of dog food are on another level.

I wouldn't work here if given a second chance, The bosses are very hatefull, and when your trying to do your job you get pulled away to do something that isn't anywhere in your job and then your force to stay there when they come back and do something else forgetting your even there.
They literally couldn’t care less about you there. The management is terrible and all over the place. The managers are extremely bias. They put their work on you.

Management decisions were strictly for the companies favor, they did little to nothing in favor of their employees, you're replaceable in their mindset. Paychecks were nice but not worth it in the end. If they know they're in the wrong with something they may give you a donut the next day
Poor communication skills between the management and the associates. Management let personal opinions cloud their judgement. Poor scheduling. Lack of coverage around the store

It's just another corporate job. They don't really care about you and push you to get email captures and all that jazz. I loved working with dogs, but the people? Not so much. High expectations low reward.

Since covid has hit its become obvious how little the company cares for its employees. People inside the store are not the issue. Horrible customers are babied, and allowed to continue their awful behavior. Every day we are at risk for covid and the best we get is employees wear masks, and customers /should/ but it’s not exactly enforced. They’re just asked to put one on. I’ve known several co workers who have just been laid off, even after loyally remaining with the company over 5 years. We end up doing the work of 3 people for half the pay. Employees are forced to feed into the companies scams that earn only the managers bonus pay. This company is a load of bull that does not care for their employees. If they did, we’d see better work life balance, better pay, and better treatment. Think again before you work or shop here.

PetSmart has abandoned it’s employees in the wake of this pandemic and  does not enforce social-distancing or proper mask wearing. Stores are allowed to become overcrowded, increasing likelihood of a spreader event.

I enjoy working here for the most part but it does not pay well compared to other jobs in the surrounding area. I was promised close to full time hours (around 38) when I was hired but have since been given 20-25 because they keep hiring people when they don’t actually need them. Corporate has too much control over the stores and payroll. This is a good job for a young college person who needs a little bit of money but definitely not somewhere you should be for a long time. Even the managers don’t make very good money even though PetSmart can very well pay them more.

I was mainly a cashier but also helped out on the floor. Its a fun job if your co workers and management are good. Most times its dealing with customers. Customers are usually nice but every now and again you get a few that make your job very difficult. There's also a 15min or 30min break depending on how long your shift is. Its very busy so lots of standing up in the same place checking out customers repeatedly. Every now and again you get to pet a dog or feed it treats while you check out the pet parent. Scheduling can also be unpredictable and inconsistent.
Love working here everyone is so nice& I’m excited to be a dog groomer ! The managers, co-workers, and customers are so awesome. I love seeing all the animals too.
The job moves in a fast past for bathers dealing with most walk ins and your bath dogs. Everyone mostly works on there own jobs and can help out other when not to busy with dogs or phone calls.
Thorough, remote training program for work at home position. Management is very supportive and encouraging.  They want you to succeed and reach your goals.
2/5 stars for the company itself, 5/5 for the store

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.
Co workers are nice, lots of opportunity for advancement. Clean place with management traininging you well. Pretty laid back and easy. Kinda quiet but there are always things to do

I worked as a Pet Care Associate for 2 years and some change. I got one 40 cent raise that was made null when minimum wage went up. This company does not reward loyalty whatsoever. Animals are sourced from breeder mills. Awful.
Worked for three years as a groomer after moving to a new state everything went down hill management was terrible at new state location that I transferred to
I enjoyed bonding with the pets and the pet parents. I enjoyed taking care of the pets making sure they were clean and healthy also presentable to the customers.

I loved working here! Watching and playing with the dogs are great but it may be a lot at times. You get to learn all about body language on dogs and cats as you work there. Youll get to meet different breeds of dogs and pet them. Eventually you could cross-train after a few months. The hotel staff are so welcoming to be around.
Season was great but they let me go the day before my birthday and one of the managers just asked me for my birthday and favorite animal it was crazy but it’s life

I started at PetSmart as a Dog Bather. The Salon Leader I had at the time was very helpful and taught me a lot. The pay was pretty good for it being my first job as well. Dog bathing can become pretty stressful. Especially during the holidays. Anyways after a year I decided to become a Pet Stylist. The way the company has the pay for Pet Stylist, is ridiculous. Hourly until you complete a certain total of dogs. Which I believe is 200. Then you receive commission. Which yeah it's great for building clientele, but if you work in a new or slower salon it feels like you are working yourself to death for little pay.

Not a very supportive environment, can be toxic and stressful with inconsistencies with management. Working with animals is great, and you can learn a lot. But your advancement is soley dependent on management and their willingness.
Fairly good teamwork situation, job tasks very well laid out (checklists for everything!).  Definitely a good temporary job - there is little opportunity for advancement, especially for females.

Petsmart as a corporate could care less about employees. For example, during covid we were open the entire time like other essential places and received zero hazard pay. We also began doing curbside pick up and received zero for the new additional work. You have to deal with so many things and they expect you to execute so many tasks for very little money. Cleaning, dealing with idiotic customers, running around hecticly, being in a smelly dirty environment, are what you should expect.
Enjoyed working at petsmart. It was fun working hands-on with animals. Didn't prefer one of the many managers and leads. Sort of unorganized crew but not a terrible part time gig

It might be a job that you get paid. But it's it really worth it? Isn't your mental health more important? Do you like being sane and enjoying your life? Don't do this to yourself. Run. Just run away while you still can.
Loved working with animals here! I loved seeing our animals and clients' animals here. The hours weren't bad and management was pretty good. They cared about my wellbeing and success.

Overall I love my job a lot. I work in the salon and have a lot of genuine love for the people in there with me, I have learned a ton at my job, and I genuinely enjoy what I do even if it was not what I was expecting to do when I moved to the area. My store operates very well, my only complaint is the corporate pressure. My store itself is great and could be just fine on its own, but the stuff we are forced to do by corporate inhibits my ability to do my best at my job. It’s a lot of pressure over things that I feel are pushy and irritating to customers, but since it’s the high ups you have to listen to them and nod your head and go along with it. I can deal with it, but it would be so much better without that weight over your head.

Profit comes first in every situation, it's all about the bottom dollar and looking good for investors (they want to take the focus off the fact that the company is tanking). Employees are expendable, loyalty and seniority mean nothing. Associates who have worked there 15 years are routinely pushed aside to make room for fresh faces. It's fun when you first start, but management must take advantage of employees and ring out every last drop of energy in order to meet goals set by corporate fops who don't understand the day-to-day struggles of working in the retail and service industry. Associates are written up for 1 minute of overtime, but are expected to do double the workload of what is humanly possible. Breaks are nonexistent. Employees regularly work through lunch and after hours but are not allowed overtime pay so usually clock out and go back to work.
It's a good place to work if you love and animals, and assisting people with their pets needs. If you're not a people person this isn't the job for you.

Petsmart is HORRIBLE they treat thier employees like garbage and will openly tell you your disposable. Store level management cant be amazing but above that are all terrible. This is the most soul crushing company ive ever worked for.

I myself love dogs and love to wake up for a job where I get to take care of pets. I worked in the PetSmart Grooming area. I was there for a very short time, but it was the best job I ever had. The team was wonderful to work with and be around in general.
I love petsmart they are a kind and loving place. The management is stellar and I wouldn’t take my pet anywhere but to them because they love and care for them like no one else.

There is very inconsistent oversight by upper management. Many protocols not strictly enforced so the employee experience is profoundly different location to location. Store leaders/district leaders make or break the experience. I've worked with some amazing people over the years that motivated me to be my best, and I've worked with some who made me want to stop trying.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

I love working with the animals and dealing with the customers. Unfortunately we got the manager that came over from Target.  It could be a better run organization if they really wanted honest feedback from the employees.

it was ok until corporate forced management turnover and then became one of the worst companies to work for. it seems to be true even to this day from what i hear from current employees even if it’s been years since i’ve worked there.
It’s a great job but it’s more than just petting dogs and some people don’t really seem to think about that before apply, it can be stressful but overall a good job

Worked here for 15 years.  Loved it up until I ended up having to work everyday including on my vacations.  Got to be overwhelming.  I miss the environment, co-workers, pet parents and the pets most of all.

Management is horrible . Also did way to much work for what you do hates it. You ask for help and you never get it . You get treated horribly . When people say I would love to work there I tell them run

I honestly loved the work I did with this company. I got to love on and take care of exotic pets daily. Dealing with customer questions and concerns was challenging and rewarding. My biggest issues came in the low wages. Some new hires were being paid more than me after having been with the company for almost 5 years. One year I only got an 8 cent raise...who does that? I was promised on more than one occasion that I would be trained as a lead for an open position at my site, then was overlooked for an outside hire or an internal promotion of a teenager.

I worked in grooming, management doesn't care about employees and training is poor. You work hard for little money. I had good co workers but the company overall lacked professionalism. They treat their groomers like children.

When I first started I was under the impression that the salon and everyone that worked in it made plenty of money but I quickly found out that that wasn’t true. Working as a Bather was exciting at first because working with dogs and puppies seems fun but then it’s not. As a bather (at my store) I was looked down upon. All the dirty work fell to me. I would close the entire salon by myself Almost everyday. I went from doing 5-6 dogs a day to 13+ without any warning. I felt overwhelmed and overworked all the time. The pay is absolute garbage. While every groomer brought home at least $800, some making up to $1400 a week. I barely made $300. The amount of work that I did and how hard I worked that was like being spit on it’s insulting how hard bathers work and how little we're paid. I found out that I was making petsmart $1000s a week (more than some groomers) while I was only being paid $200. The management basically told me to deal with it whenever I confronted them about my pay. I loved working with the dogs but I hated how I was being taken advantage of. I wouldn’t recommend this job to anyone because you are literally the salons slave. I hope it gets better but I doubt it will.

I worked at 3 different stores, and they varied based on management and coworkers. The first store was my first job and I always felt appreciated and got along with my coworkers for the most part. The job can be boring at times, especially if you are constantly stuck on the register. However, I was able to transfer stores with ease, and move up fairly quickly.

Poor management throughout my store, but I'm a petstist, make 50% commission and work very hard so I'm a happy camper financially. I've spoken with corporate and it seems to be a great company to work for but it isn't necessarily reflected in the actual stores.

It was a good job, great coworkers and a place to get to know shoppers in your community. You have regulars that you get to know and their pets who you bond with. Coworkers can become friends for life but despite everything it's still retail. High expectations, some rude customers, poor consistency with management, poor hours and little flexibility unless you've been around long enough to earn it.

It's a great temporary job for people with little to no experience, who love animals and enjoy getting to learn about them. You don't make a lot of money in the beginning and they expect you to do more than a normal office/9 to 5 kind of job. Expect to clean, learn to work the registers and assist customers with everyday questions. Most of the staff is friendly, so definitely ask them questions when you aren't sure about something.
Typical retail problems. Not enough hours for people to be where they need to be. Pay was decent for any leads but GM was always overworked. Company takes short cuts long term for store well being
This is most definitely a starter job that I would work at while young. Management was ok and coworkers were fun to work with. Overall nice people to work with

It was okay but it got my foot in the door to work with animals. Management did not care at all about the animals. The hamsters all had wet tail, birds were stressed, cats in adoption died... just horrible stuff.

My time here was awesome and I loved it! I loved working with the animals and my coworkers and management were wonderful. Everyone working here was really nice and really enjoyed their job. They put in 200% every shift. Unfortunately I needed full time hours and the pay was a little lower... had I been able to be employed full time I would have never left. It really was a great place to work.

In my experience working there, the job was very much enjoyable. The work was fairly easy, managers were always very helpful and had your back most if not all the time. Very laid back environment, hardly ever any stress except for inventory time of the year or the holidays, but that's anywhere. I only left because of a personal dispute, but had that never happened, I would've loved to have moved up in the company.

This job started out great but it turned out to be one of the worst places I ever worked. The people that worked there were incompetant and extremely lazy. Nobody cared about the dogs all they cared about was where their next dollar was coming from.... Went through 3 salon leaders in 3 years and not one of them actually liked dogs or even liked their jobs. Upper management did nothing about complaints. Anybody that actually loved their jobs were smart enough to leave there.

I was a bather in the grooming salon, and I really enjoyed it at first, but they promised to send me through their grooming academy program to become a stylist, but it was easier for them to keep me where I was at, so they ignored me and refused to promote me. A family member of mine was suffering from cancer, and my first time calling out of my shift for going to the hospital with him, the salon manager told me to call my ONE coworker who was also a bather to cover my appointments for the day. After that, I turned in my two week notice, but I should have just quit outright. They don't pay you enough for dealing with large, rowdy, and difficult dogs, and I frequently got back injuries from having to bend over all day long to bathe and groom dogs that had to be tethered to the floor, since they were too big to fit in the tubs. My one store was bad, maybe others were better, but that was my experience.
Bosses don't care about how you are treated. Just worry about getting your numbers. Constant raises for everyone even if they don't deserve it. Many lazy people just blocking production.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

Always worked overtime because we were understaffed. Pay wasn't worth my time. Always was about sales and never the animals. The only good thing was about the job were my coworkers at the time but after a few started to move on to better opportunities, my time there wasn't long either. Everybody was overworked and underpaid, including the managers.

All about the numbers and they do not care for their staff. They act like they do, but at the end of the day they do not. They cut hours to the bare minimum but expect the same results. Terrible company.
Overall ok place to work. If you are looking for long term with ways to move up you should go somewhere else. In a pinch they will at least give you hours to work.

If you have a love for animals, this is the place to work. I truly enjoyed working with the animals and getting to take care of them. Most of the associates strive for a good working environment and to provide the best care for the animals and the customers. The management in Twin Falls, Idaho is not the best, but is not terrible. Some management cares for its employees and other management can be toxic. The other downfalls to the positions at Petsmart is the pay and hours. I always strive to provide the best customer service and quality work. After a year of continuously asking for a pay raise or to become a full-time employee instead of part-time, nothing ever changed except for an increased work load. Now that I have quit my position there, I am making a better wage with less physical labor.
Good company. Very busy pace. Lots of perks always complimenting you on good job. Safety conscious. Fair pay and ability to make a bonus check. Lots of OT
Overworked and underpaid, mistreated and talked down to, makes you miserable and unhappy, feels like you are spending every second of your time for no reward.
Constantly understaffed and extremely rude customers during rush hour times with no help from management. Very exhausting and constantly overworked. Doggie day camp worse job I ever had.

It was a great experience if you like working with animals and customer service. It's sad when you have to take care of sick animals because there's a 50% chance they can pass away even though they are treated by their own vet. you have to be strong willed to take care of these sick animals, otherwise emotions can get over you. I was a Pet Care Specialist and I love this job but the pay is what is low for all that I did, the rest was good from my 2 managers to the other peers. I  had a great time.
The team was nice and working with animals is great but overall management was below average. Only one person stood out as caring while the rest were no help at all.

I enjoyed my time with PetSmart. As my first job it helped me grow my skills in the animal field and laid down the building blocks for my own personal growth. The quality of your management team will greatly determine how much you like working here. Some managers do not care about the animals in their care.
PetSmart offers great service along with great product and care.  The company goals and policies are fair and easily understood.  PetSmart takes care of their employees as well as the community.
It was okay. Not paid enough for the amount of work required. That’s most places now though. The customers were great though. It did not feel team friendly.

I loved what I did but the drama was unbearable. Being a bather the groomers treat you like dirt and make your workload harder on purpose. When I talked to my coworkers about it the girls said it’s different when you become a groomer...  They completely work you to death and take advantage. Maybe I just had a bad location, but I wouldn’t recommend working as a bather.
Was a fun place to work when dealing with all the animals, but the pay isn’t enough. Good job for a part time of college student who is in need of flexible hours, but should pay more.
I loved working with animals and dealing with customers. Manager is usually flexible when you want a different schedule, so that's nice. Had like 2 days off a week.

This is a good job for a teenager. Management has it's clicks and you have to be in that click to advance.  It's good for a starter job and experience but after you get that, move on. Pay is terrible.
management is a joke, pay is a joke. hours typically sucked. coworkers were usually cool since we all love animals. if you love animals and need a part time job this is for you

Benefits were great upper management not so much great pay a week paid vacation plus sick days unachievable expectations from corporate task management not understood at higher level not enough associates working

A typical day at work was busy and stressful. The only enjoyable part was interacting with the store animals and customer's pets. It's decent for a first job, but the managers/customers can take a toll on your mental health sometimes.

There is so much emphasis on making plan that the employees are worked into the ground.  Coworkers were great and management tries their best but nothing can meet the high standards that corporate puts onto them!

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.
very simple cashier job. Customers are the toughest. management is ok. the most enjoyable part is being able to see all of the animals come into the store.

Don’t become a dog groomer. It’s a miserable career with zero advancement-that goes for almost all grooming jobs, everywhere. Little to no benefits and never get a raise because you are paid commission.

This position (pets hotel associate) is great. It can seem overwhelming at first but you get into this little groove and know everything like the back of your hand in no time. It is so much more than interacting with animals though. It’s fast paced, can be very chaotic during peak hours/days and yea, it’s still retail. You will be dealing with pet parents just as frequently, if not more than animals! I think it can be a lot for teenagers/young adults (the main draw to this sort of job) to handle sometimes... But it makes for good learning experiences. As with any company management varies store to store but everyone at my location is awesome. :)

I was hired for the weekend shift, 3 12 hour shifts. Due to Covid they enforce everyone to work 60 hours every week. This destroyed the work/ life balance and caused issues in my schooling. They could’ve prioritize essential products such as food and medicine instead of toys and holiday products instead of overworking every employee.
I love it! Great hours and animals. People were nice. I love all the new animals. Very chilled. They had a great grooming service there. Never saw anything bad.

Very fun to work here, but sometimes the communication between managers is not good, and you will get in trouble for doing what one manager says and not the other. You really need to listen to the head manager, if another one asks you to do something contradictory to the leader, tell them so as not to get into senseless trouble

Team is awesome.  Managers care about their staff and the pets they sell in the building. Sometimes we are not given the hours needed to do the job they ask from corporate.  Corporate needs to work in stores for a week to see the real daily activities

I think it depends mostly on your store, I had some great mangers/employees, but also bad ones. There is a lot of focus on meeting certain metrics and some days you feel understaffed, especially when closing.

I left because the new person who got promoted was too much of a mean person she was all about getting you into trouble so she could look good at her new position and get her friends in the job.So I left plus I felt really bad at how locked up the dogs would-be for months even.id never leave my dog at a place like that,they don't even get to go outside like ever thats torture especially those that are left by their owners there..it's really sad.

I enjoyed working in the Pet Hotel even though it could get crazy. We had a great team! Store management was poor and a revolving door. Store managers were not trained for Pet Hotel so they were never any help.

After working at my location for 7 months I did not trust petsmart to look after my dog. While at the Petshotel people paid for their dogs to have private 15-30 min playdates and we only have them 12-15 no matter what. (Grooming was aways lovely though)

Started with bad original lead and management  and got sent to grooming academy unprepared. Came back to a new salon lead and is getting better.  It can be physically exhausting, as well as mentally. You must have patience and enjoy being around dogs. The pay in the salon is not good until you finish most of the training after their grooming academy.
It has its ups and downs. Like any job. You can bring your dog here which is nice. Pay is not enough though. The call volume can be overwhelming and the systems feel very outdated.

You learn a lot about petcare but it’s just another corporation out there to make money. Not so great benefits other than product discounts but the overall discount is sad. Stressful and dirty. The company should stop selling fish and small animals as the facilities are lingering with disease and disrepair.

Even though I was only here for a short time. I LOVED EVERY SINGLE DAY OF MY JOB! I was sad to leave. However I am happy for the opportunity to have the experiences. I learned so much in the short time, and I will cherish my time with the salon staff and memories we made forever.

I spent almost two years with PetSmart and hated every second of it. Management is terrible, you have to beg to take a 30 minute break after working for 10 hours straight. The way they treat animals is horrendous. I never want to work there again nor do I want to shop there.
How is this company still open? This was the worse job I ever had. They don’t train properly they don’t treat pets properly they over work pay is horrid. They have poor ethics with animals.
Loved working with the animals and adopting them out to good homes. Management was good and employees were very kind. Some annoying costumers but that's to be expected.

The management team at Lynnwood store is a do as I say, not as I do group. Most staff do not care about the welfare of animals, they are viewed as dollar signs and not a viable little life. The fish are ##constantly infected. Safety and sanitation procedures are not followed. Most staff are unprofessional behind the backs of eachother and customers. Young staff play on their phones constantly and do not like to be told what to do. They need a safe space to pout when they do not get their way. Management will write off store products from the shelves like can dog or cat food, then demand with consequences the staff solicit customers for cash or food donations.. Management talk behind the backs of staff and turn one against another.
This job tends to rely highly on if management is good. The schedule can be flexible and there's some good dogs, but those are the only pros.

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

Worked as a pet care specialist mostly playing with dogs all day. Day camp is from 9-5 with an hour break from 12-1. You will mainly be in camp when you first start but once you get the hang of it you’ll be out of camp cleaning, preparing lunches or dinners, and helping the front staff.
It was too long ago to remember properly. I said that this was too long ago to properly remember, however the supervisor and management were hugely underqualified and had no interpersonal skills.
Back in the day, knowing ALL departments was a HUGE help; filling in when short staffed.

Employees are trained to know all areas of the store entirely too fast.  This job would have been way less stressful if they trained an employee in one for department a week or two before moving on to the next.

Sometimes rewarding. The amount of work that is to be done in the petcare department is not worth the pay.  There’s a lot of tasks to be done in a short amount of time while also having to help customers almost always on your own.
I worked here for over 2 years and loved it, it was fun and I got along with everyone great. If I could have had. amore family oriented schedule i would have stayed

Pay is awful unless you're a groomer or manager. You get passed over for promotions and the pay raises are a joke. They'll often schedule you to work closing and opening shifts and will take advantage of you whenever possible.

The work itself was fun, but the management was horrendous. Every month we would get a new manager in the store with new expectations. I was practically bullied out of my position and job in general. My coworkers were some of the best people I have ever met, but the management needs serious work.

Not sure if it's just my location but there was very poor management. Overall, everyone was nice but most of the time the store was on fire. Not to mention there wasn't enough compensation for all the work you're doing.

The management and HR are HORRIBLE. They only care about what work is getting done. They also are really bad liars and manipulaters. They will fire you for using the time you have to go home wether if it’s for being sick or emergencies. Anything.
Petsmart only cares about money and forcing you to overwork yourself. They need to get their corporate people off the backs of the stores...and they don't care about you during this pandemic.
learning to groom at Petsmart was ok. Nothing special. Learned the basics and safety protocols. Benefits were decent. They constantly asked you to do more and groom more.
I loved working here. Great managers and enjoyable work. There is a positive atmosphere because people love their pets. Management worked with me and gave me good opportunities.

The best part about working for this company was working with animals and building relationships with co-workers and pet parents. The company itself does not care or value you and make it very clear that you are replaceable, regardless of how hard you work. They are an insatiable company and never recognize accomplishments, only criticize the things that can be done "better," or the things that you did "wrong."

you’ll never be fully compensated for your work. petsmart is a selfish company that only cares about money. i worked in the store and in the salon and the ONLY good thing about the job were my regular clients (the dogs specifically because most of the customers were rude) and my fellow salon associates. i was treated horribly by core management and never received any support. A coworker of mine got really sick and couldn’t come into work (before covid) and they demoted her from being a groomer because of it. They only care about themselves. Don’t waste your time

I will start off with, PetSmart has always been this much of a mess, this has not changed due to the recent pandemic. My store had new management very frequently and could not keep employees because of unfair expectations for employees not scheduled to work. If you did not come in when they called, you would be punished. The managers would often fight amongst themselves and pit lower employees against each other. Departments were poorly managed, never maintained properly, and safely regulations were completely ignored. I had to do several safety walks and was told by higher ups to falsify monthly safety inspections for store performance.

I enjoyed my time on the front end as a cashier, especially seeing people bring their pets into the store. I learned a lot about different animal care in my five years there, and I eventually was cross trained as a receptionist in the salon. I loved being a salon receptionist, and it inspired me to eventually switch careers and focus on admin positions as a specialty. The customers and pets were the best part of this job. The schedule unfortunately fluctuated wildly from week to week, and the management was a mixed bag. Some of them were amazing, and others were petty and small-minded.

I couldn't complain about pay or benefits. The overall job I enjoyed. The customers and routine wasn't bad. Computer systems completely outdated, EXTREME issues with management, training non existent, daily and weekly goals, though obtainable were placing heavy burdens on a single person, and again, upper management was horrible. I ended up quitting upset and furious and in turn was accused of stealing and banned from ever working for Petsmart again.  And it was truly upsetting because I worked hard and gave it my all only to be treated badly, mainly because I was female. Even though it was almost all women in the store.. except for the store manager

Because it's not a super huge store it was a pretty easy job for stocking. We had our time in the morning before the store opened to pack out the truck, which was nice and uninterrupted. It was also a big plus having people like you, with a love for animals, to work with too.

I liked my job here until I got laid off because of COVID. I’d still be working there otherwise. My boss was very supportive and the people I worked with were great and friendly people. I pretty much worked side by side with the inventory leader to replenish the store. Got to wear my headphones, lots of independence when I wanted it and support when I needed it. But that’s all a tribute to my managers!

My experience at PetSmart.  The employees are welcoming, concerning, and supportive.  The schedule is flexible.  I learned a variety of skills needed for the store to be successful.  the management encourages employee success.  The workplace and culture is fantastic.The hardest part of the job was when I tried to work as a groomer.  I was not successful at that so the manager found what I was successful at.  The most enjoyable part of the job was the interaction with customers.

A lot of people believe that working with dogs is all fun and games, but it’s not. A lot of the time you’re in the salon, they’re are going to be dogs that are scared, it’s happens. They could be unsocialized or have had a bad experience at the groomers. You have to be comfortable holding dogs, grinding nails, etc. It’s a very rewarding job and I wouldn’t change my job for anything in the world, I absolutely love bathing pups, but it isn’t for everyone. I need to me patient and confident, especially since dogs can tell when your nervous. I would recommend this job to anyone who really wants to work with dogs, but it’s not the easiest job in the world.

Worked here for three years. Gained experience here that I needed. Honestly, management makes or breaks the job itself. First two years loved my managers and enjoyed coming to work, last year on the job with new management made it horrible and many people quit. They make it easy to be able to work in different departments or move up, pay is not great and the raises aren’t great either. It is stable though and especially if it’s your first job. It’s retail mixed with animal care depending on the department you work in. Get to see cute animals  :)

Horrible work environment in the salon. They do nothing but talk about you and belittle you. There are definitely favorites among the manager and certain groomers who are allowed to do whatever they want to. It's like being in high school all over again. They never follow rules but expect you to follow them otherwise you get into trouble. When you talk to management, they do nothing and it only makes the situation worse.
Department management is great, store manager was often hiding in the office and not involved with running the store. Learned a lot and enjoyed my time here.
Coworkers were nice and management was alright. There were barely any hours though and they didn't gave us hazard pay; other places were paying $2 more during the pandemic.

I worked under a management team that was very good. I've heard stories of other locations having bad management, so that can vary from store to store. Overall, I learned a lot about animals working there, whether it be from my own research or from the (nice) customers that came in. I had a really good experience at PetSmart, but I never really got the chance to advance my career there.

You take the good with the bad here, I guess. Depending on your size and experience this may not be a hard job at all, but as a 90 lb person thats probably one of the first words I’d use to describe my job. That or frustrating.

It was nice working here.  I worked in several different locations in different states over the years.  Every salon is very different. I worked under several very good managers and one absolutely insane store.  PetSmart tries to care about it's groomers but that can be lost when management wants you to continue working on an aggressive dog to meet the sales quota.
Customer care of the animals is a lot of work and they should pay more. Easy going place to work. Management is great with working around your schedule, so its great job for students.

A terrible company filled with upper management that was borderline evil. It's almost like it was a requirement to work there. After they were sold, all they cared about was cutting hours and overworking their staff.

After working here for about 6 months as a bather, I had to leave there were no real educators to teach how to properly bathe a dog and the leadership was very all over the place. We didn't have a manager and on top of that, the groomers would be rude and force the bathers to do stuff that didn't want to do.

I was an early morning stocker, which meant I worked with two other people to fully download the trucks. Problem is, management does not understand how quickly you are able to download the trucks and fully put out all the product. They have a 'math equation' to measure how long it should take you, but it is almost always off. Even if you are moving no-stop, knocking out carts left and right, you will always end up with one additional pallet that you just couldn't get to.

The company itself isn’t too bad. It’s the management in the store that will make or break the experience you have there. With the store I was at, management only ever cared about their favorites and numbers. They were horrible with scheduling with school, would talk bad behind your back over simple things and will act rude and disrespectful if you have family issues going on. Most of the positions are part time so never go in expecting to get 20 or more hours a week.

Petsmart only cares about making money they don’t care about the mental or physical health of their employees or their animals for that matter. I would recommend not working at PetSmart unless you enjoy getting paid Bologna  money to do crazy amounts of job responsibilities.
didnt expect people ro be unprofessional. store was clean at least. i had less hours over time. they do run a background check and no they dont drug test. but could be different for each interviewee.

Don’t stay here long. In all locations I worked at, favoritism and cliques run rampant and unchecked. Managers often cover their own mistakes and laziness by assigning huge amounts of work to unqualified departments and guilt newer employees into staying for longer shifts or coming in early/on days off. There’s a highschool level of hazing that happens within management and senior employees. If you aren’t immediately well-liked by the upper crust, you find yourself getting assigned janitorial roles — cleaning up all of the pet accidents, taking care of food spills, cleaning restrooms — and nonstop register shifts for 9 hours. Your shifts will consist of the least-liked managers and the least-reliable employees. If you’re well-liked immediately, you’ll find yourself getting pulled into the office for snacks, given advancement opportunities before they are posted publicly and offered more desirable shifts with more efficient coworkers. Advancement opportunities are extremely difficult to get unless all of management likes you, which often means answering phone calls on your days off and doing things that are way above your pay grade for no extra compensation. Employees are promptly thrown under the bus for any mistakes management or other departments make. I witnessed several coworkers get mocked or told they were lying during traumatic events such as illness, family/pet death, and accidents/injury that occurred outside of work. You don’t get paid enough for this.

Upon arrival at Petsmart, I admit it was alot to digest. Started as part of the management team. Which has been a blessing. Learning things as you grow. Management team is supportive. Corporate is supportive, as well as, DM. Happy to be a part of the team at Petsmart. Every day is an adventure. Enjoy working with the public, assisting with their pet needs.

As a groomer, in my opinion you are paid well.  It's really based on what level of stress u can handle. You can groom 5-6 pups a day and it's breezy or you can do 8-10 dogs a day and feel the pressure. But don't think u are there to JUST groom. You will also be cleaning, answering phones, walk-ins, bringing dogs in and out and depending on management... they can be annoying....but that's their job. It's a great stepping stone into the grooming world.

There are many things that are performed that anyone with proper animal care knowledge knows are not in the best interest of the animals.
